summary: On August 23, 2005 the French Sports newspaper L'Equipe charged that Lance Armstrong used the drug EPO in 1999. Armstrong strongly denied the charge. The French sports minister, the Tour de France director and the chief executive of the USCycling said that since the tests used as a basis for the charges were inadequate no action would be taken against the cyclist. A Texas scientist attributed Armstrong's performance to his modern training approach, not EPO. A specialist in the fight against doping in sports, however, suggested that Armstrong had used a range of banned substances.    On May 23, 2005 sports newspaper L'Equip reported Armstrong illegally used erythropoietin for the 1999 Tour de France, based on urine samples examined outside World Anti-Doping Agency protocols, but linked to Armstrong by L'Equip, in violation of WADA anonymity rules. Tour Director Leblanc accepted the charge uncritically, but discipline seemed unlikely because WADA testing was impossible. The French Sports Minister agreed. USA Cycling, Miguel Indurain, and Ed Coyle defended Armstrong. Armstrong took erythropoietin during cancer treatments before 1999. An International Cycling Union investigation of 1999 drug testing is pending. Alessandro Donati suggested without evidence that Armstrong used other banned substances.    French newspaper L'Equipe reported new tests by a French laboratory on backup urine samples Lance Armstrong provided at the 1999 Tour de France tested positive for EPO. Armstrong strongly denied the charges and questioned the validity of the tests. USA Cycling, fellow cyclists, scientists and French fans have defended Armstrong. Defenders attacked the report as unethical and the laboratory results as flawed and unsound. Armstrong is suing a British newspaper for printing excerpts from a book which insinuated he had been doping. An Italian specialist believes Armstrong used other drugs, too. However, he has never been found guilty of doping.    A French newspaper accused Lance Armstrong of using the illegal performance-enhancing drug, EPO in 1999 to win his first of seven consecutive Tours. The laboratory conducting the tests couldn't confirm the samples were Armstrong's, but the newspaper said it decoded the labels from samples identifying Armstrong. Armstrong strongly denies this charge. The director of UT's Human Performance Laboratory, who studied Armstrong's physiology from 1992 to 1999, stated that Armstrong's record winning streak is explained by his years of training and a modest diet in the spring months before the Tour de France. </text> <scu uid="2" label="French newspaper L'Equipe charged Lance Armstrong used erythropoietin (EPO) in 1999">  <contributor label="A summary: In November, Colombian police arrested a FARC assassin, the army killed a FARC leader, and the court approved the extradition of a FARC chief to the US to face narcotics trafficking and money laundering charges. FARC rebels murdered four indigenous Indian leaders in less than a week. The government and FARC continued to argue over details of a prisoner swap. The UN urged Colombia to speed up negotiations for hostage release. December 2, the government announced it would pardon 23 FARC members to facilitate reaching a humanitarian accord with FARC. Colombian police may have kidnapped a FARC rebel in Venezuela.     FARC rejected a government proposal to hold talks aimed at exchanging rebels for hostages held by the guerillas. FARC asked the president to grant them the two southern demilitarized zones, before discussions could take place. The government denied their request because it has to guarantee the safety of the people across the country. The United Nations urged hostage release. The rebel groups released 12 hostages. The Columbian government plans to pardon more than 30 members of FARC as they negotiate a prisoner swap.    FARC rejected the government proposal for talks aimed at exchanging jailed rebels for hostages unless two southern counties were demilitarized. The government rejected that demand but released 50 jailed guerillas to build confidence. FARC followed with release of five kidnap victims. FARC killed another indigenous leader, Pervis Pacheco of the Kankuamo Indians and are believed to have killed the leader of Arhuaco Indians. Columbia's Supreme Court approved extradition of a FARC chief, among others, to the US to face charges of narco-trafficking and money laundering. The government was to pardon 23 FARC members as the two sides negotiate prisoner exchanges.    The Colombian government again refused FARC's request for two southern demilitarized zones before prisoner exchange discussions. FARC holds 1600 hostages. Police arrested a top FARC assassin responsible for over 50 assassinations, including a mayor and town councilor, and ordering hostages killed when families failed to pay ransoms. FARC killed four indigenous leaders of the Kankuamo, Yanacona and Arhuaca Indians. The government released 50 jailed guerrillas and pardoned 23. Five FARC rebels died in a clash with the army. Colombia approved extradition of a FARC chief to the US. A FARC leader was seized in Venezuela and moved to Colombia.   </text> <scu uid="1" label="Colombian police arrested a FARC assassin">  <contributor label="Colombian police arrested a FARC assassin"> summary: A Russian mini-submarine containing 7 submariners became trapped for 3 days on the sea floor in eastern Russia. The submarine was entangled in fishing nets and/or a coastal monitoring system antenna. Russian rescue attempts to free and raise the submarine were unsuccessful. Russia requested international help. Japan, Britain and the U.S. responded with rescue equipment. The British Navy used a robotic vehicle to free the submarine which then surfaced. The crew were in satisfactory condition and taken for medical examination. Russia's naval equipment has not been upgraded as promised by Putin following the Kursk submarine tragedy.    On Aug. 4, 2005 the Russian navy, working desperately to disengage a small military submarine with seven crew snagged by underwater cables at a depth of 625 feet off the Kamchatka peninsula, called for international help. Japan dispatched four vessels, Britain's Royal Navy sent a submersible Super Scorpio unmanned robotic vehicle and the U. S. Pacific fleet sent two vehicles similar to the British. Estimates varied as to how much oxygen remained for the entrapped crewmen. The British vehicle arrived first and on Aug. 7 the submarine was cut loose and the crewmen were found all alive.    For nearly three days, a Russian mini-submarine was trapped about 600 feet below the surface of the Beryozovaya Bay. The AS-28 became snarled in the cables of an undersea coastal monitoring system. Throughout the ordeal, there were varying estimates of the remaining oxygen supply. When Russian attempts to tow the sub to shallower water failed, they sent out an urgent call for international help. Japan, Britain and the US all dispatched vessels to aid the rescue efforts. A British Super Scorpio robotic underwater vehicle succeeded in freeing the mini-sub. All seven sailors aboard were rescued in satisfactory condition.    A small Russian submarine with seven crew members was trapped on the seabed off the Kamchatka Peninsula late on 4 August. The Russians tried desperately to pull the sub to shallower waters but those efforts failed. They sought international assistance. Japan sent four naval vessels, the U.S. sent three underwater vehicles, but the British were the first to arrive, with remote control submersibles. They cut away the net or undersea cables trapping the sub, enabling it to rise to the surface after almost three days at the bottom. All seven crew members were alive and well. </text> <scu uid="1" label="Mini-submarine trapped underwater">  <contributor label="mini-submarine...became trapped...on the sea floor">   <part summary: Charles Taylor disappeared 48 hours after the Nigerian government rescinded his political asylum. Bowing to international pressure the Liberian government was preparing to take Taylor into custody to extradite him to Sierra Leone. United Nations chief Kofi Annan requested West African countries to deny Taylor refuge and arrest him. Taylor was arrested the next day by Nigerian police while attempting to cross the border into Cameroon. Upon his involuntary return to Liberia he was flown by the United Nations peacekeeping force to Sierra Leone and was read the arrest warrant. Taylor will appear before the Special Court on April 3.    On the night of March 27, 2006 Charles Taylor vanished. His spiritual advisor said he was hiding somewhere in West Africa. On March 29 Taylor was arrested while attempting to cross over into Cameroon. He was detained under armed guard and then placed on a presidential jet bound for Liberia. He left Monrovia, Liberia an hour after arrival on a UN helicopter to Freetown, Sierra Leone where he was delivered to the UN-backed Special Court for Sierra Leone. He was due to make his first court appearance on April 3 at 3 p.m.    Taylor vanished the night of March 27, after the Nigerian government said it would end his asylum and allow him to face indictment by an international court in Sierra Leone. On March 29 he was arrested by Nigeria police trying to escape into Cameroon. He was detained under guard, flown to Liberia, arrested by UN peacekeeping forces, and extradited by helicopter to Sierra Leone on March 30. The Special Court in Sierra Leon indicted Taylor on 11 counts of crimes against humanity, making him the first African head of state to face an international war crimes tribunal.    Taylor vanished two days after President Obasanjo said Liberia could take Taylor into custody. Nigerian police arrested Taylor a day after his escape, as he tried to cross into Cameroon with sacksful of dollars and euros. He was detained under armed guard in a military camp before being put in handcuffs on a presidential jet Wednesday bound for Liberia. An hour after arrival he left for Sierra Leone aboard a UN helicopter. He was to make his first court appearance on Monday, April 3, 2006, the first African head of state to face an international war crimes tribunal. </text> <scu uid="105" label="Taylor became the first summary: The directors of Fannie met on Dec. 19 to decide Raines' fate, but the meeting concluded without any announcement of a decision. On Dec. 21 Raines resigned with his departure structured as an early retirement. The directors' decision in favor of Raines' retirement rather than dismissal would reap him $8.7 million in deferred payments and an annual pension of more than $1 million. On Jan. 21, 2005, however, Fannie announced that Raines would be denied the cash bonus that he would have received for 2004.    By October 12, 2004 the U.S. Attorney's Office in Washington was investigating Fannie Mae CEO Franklin Raines, who denied wrongdoing, after a caustic September 22 Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight report vetted by the SEC, charged that Fannie Mae violated Financial Accounting Standard 133 and FAS-91, inflating Fannie Mae's reported net earnings by $9 billion, so that Raines and other top executives received maximum bonuses of $27.1 million vice no bonuses, and got higher, allegedly manipulated, prices for their own sales of Fannie Mae stock. The Justice Department told Fannie Mae to preserve documents related to OFHEO's report.    Raines testified to Congress that he expected to be held accountable if his interpretation of the accounting rules was not accepted. The chief accountant of the SEC ruled that Fannie Mae violated accounting standards overstating its profits by 38 percent since January 2001. Raines is seeking a vote of confidence from the directors as he struggles to survive criminal investigation. Raines retired under pressure from federal regulators. Raines will be denied bonuses for 2004 as Fannie Mae eliminated bonuses for top executives.    The SEC ruled that Fannie Mae had overstated its profits by 38 per cent in the years 2001-2004. The OFHEO held Raines responsible the company's emphasisis on earnings over accuracy and demanded significant changes in senior management. On 21 December, Raines took early retirement with millions of dollars in benefits and stock, plus an annual pension of over one million dollars. The company still faced a Justice Department criminal investigation, an SEC civil investigation, further OFHEO examination of its accounting, and several class-action lawsuits. As of 21 January, Fannie Mae was withholding millions in bonuses for top executives. </text> <scu uid="1" label="The directors of Fannie met on Dec. 19 to decide Raines' fate">  <contributor summary: Bamboo shoots must be properly prepared to avoid consuming naturally produced hydrogen cyanide. Bamboo can help makeshift buildings better withstand earthquakes. Innovative bamboo products include: hardwood flooring, paneling, cabinets, countertops, utensils, plates, bowls, cutting boards, shower curtains, and products based on fiber, fiber pulps or veneers. Bamboo's has greater tensile strength than steel. It can be harvested every 3 to 5 years, but entire bamboo stands die-off every 60 years, threatening crop collapse and endangering China's endangered Giant Pandas, who are dependent on arrow bamboo.    Bamboo has many uses. In the home, it is used for flooring, kitchen cabinets, counter tops, and chairs. India is allowing its islands that were struck by the tsunami, to build makeshift houses from bamboo and other woods, which can withstand quakes. Ethiopia hopes to optimize ways of producing bamboo to reduce poverty. Large areas of arrow bamboo provide food for giant pandas in northwest China. Now they are suffering from hunger because large tracts of arrow bamboo died. It takes 10-15 years for new plants to grow.     Bamboo is increasing used for household items and furniture. Its main use remains as a sturdy alternative for hardwood flooring. It has greater tensile strength than steel and costs less and lasts longer than oak flooring. It is environmentally friendly and sustainable since it grows fast and can be harvested within five years. Bamboo shoots are a traditional part of Asian cuisine but must be properly prepared to avoid causing harm. The bamboo plant is the staple panda food. But when the plant flowers and produces seeds, pandas will not eat it and are in danger of starving.    Bamboo is used for flooring, paneling, and furnishings. Its tensile strength is greater than steel, it's harvestable in 3-5 years, and it's inexpensive. India makes bamboo housing for earthquake survivors. Ethiopia is developing its extensive bamboo commercially with China's help. A pulp mill for bamboo-like Arundo donax would benefit Alabama economically but residents fear the plant's invasiveness. California imported it for windbreaks. Giant pandas are increasing in China due to expanded bamboo forests and moving pandas when local bamboo flowers and becomes inedible. KFC in China substitutes bamboo shoots for coleslaw. Incorrect preparation of fresh shoots risks hydrogen cyanide exposure. </text> <scu uid="1" label="Bamboo is increasingly used for household items and furniture">  <contributor label="Bamboo is summary: Specialists in several countries confirmed that Viktor Yushchenko was deliberately poisoned with pure TCDD, a lethal form of dioxin which causes disfigurement and long term health issues. The poisoning investigation is ongoing. The earlier disputed presidential election was declared fraudulent and invalid by the Supreme Court. A repeat election was mandated. Foreign observers will help secure an honest election. Yushchenko was elected president of the Ukraine with 51.99 percent of the vote. As he took the oath of office Yushchenko vowed to improve economic conditions in the Ukraine. Viktor Yanukovych vowed to appeal the election results to the Supreme Court.    The Ukraine Supreme Court invalidated the November 21 election, due to election fraud. Yushchenko's ingested poison was identified as pure TCDD, a rare highly toxic form of Dioxin. Yushchenko deferred criminal investigations until after the repeat election December 26. Parliament failed to pass Yuschenko's election reforms, but the Constitutional Court ruled for expanded home voting, which helped Yushchenko. Yushchenko supporters pushed for Yanukovich's resignation; instead he took a leave of absence to run his campaign. The dual U.S.-Ukraine citizen Yushchenko won the Presidency 51.99% to 44.20% for Yanukovich. Yanukovich said he would appeal to the Supreme Court, without much hope.    In December, doctors determined conclusively that Yushchenko was deliberately poisoned with the most lethal form of dioxin. Prosecutors reopened a criminal investigation into his attempted murder. Yushchenko was sure that Ukrainian authorities were responsible. He fell ill on September 6, after having food and drinks with the head of the Security Service of Ukraine and others. The Ukraine Supreme Court overturned the November runoff election results due to fraud, and Parliament enacted new anti-fraud election reforms in December. Yushchenko won a repeat runoff on December 26 and took office in January, his face still disfigured by the poison.    Yushchenko was sworn in as President of Ukraine on Sunday 23 January. In a third round of voting on 26 December, Yushchenko won 51.99% of the vote to Yanukovich's 44.20%. The Supreme Court had annulled the results of the second round of voting because of election fraud. That decision followed 17 days of massive popular protests called the "Orange Revolution" after Yushchenko's campaign color. Doctors confirmed that Yushchenko had been deliberately poisoned with TCDD, the most lethal form of dioxin. Blood tests revealed levels of dioxin "more than 1000 times" normal. Yushchenko will need treatment for months if not years. </text> <scu uid="40" label="Yushchenko poisoned with TCDD (dioxin)">  <contributor label="Specialists...confirmed...Yushchenko was deliberately summary: On June 29, 2005 the Canadian House of Commons passed legislation to legalize gay marriage on a national basis. In Britain a Civil Partnership Act took effect on Dec. 5, 2005 granting some legal rights and tax benefits to gay couples. By March 2006 homosexual rights advocates were demonstrating in favor of gay marriage in Taipei, Taiwan. In the U.S. a Maryland judge threw out a law banning gay marriage, lawmakers in New Hampshire defeated a proposed constitutional amendment banning gay marriage, and seven states were prepared to vote on such amendments in November.    Texas legislators will vote on a constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage that is not expected to pass. New Hampshire lawmakers defeated a constitutional ban on gay marriage. The issue is under debate in courts in Maryland, California, New Jersey, New York and Washington State. The US government does not recognize same-sex marriage. Massachusetts is the only state to legalize it, although Vermont and Connecticut allow legalized civil unions. Canada passed landmark legislation to legalize gay marriage everywhere in the country. However, gay marriage is not legal in Sweden and Taiwan. Many countries have legalized civil unions, but not gay marriage.    Canada passed legislation authorizing gay marriages and granting same-sex couples legal rights equal to those in traditional unions. In Sweden, civil unions between homosexuals are legal and the government will decide if the law should be changed to include marriage. Under the Civil Partnership Act passed in Britain, homosexual couples will have the same rights as heterosexual couples. Texas legislation to amend the constitution to ban same-sex marriages is being discussed. Homosexual rights activists urged the Taiwan government to grant homosexual couples the right to marry.    Canada and Spain legalized gay marriage and Britain allowed civil partnerships in 2005. Germany and Switzerland allow registered partnerships. Portugal recognizes de facto couples regardless of sex. Croatia gives gay couples rights equal to de facto heterosexual couples. New Zealand gives them rights equal to married couples. South Africa allows gay couple adoptions. Sweden's Lutheran Church approved gay partnership blessing ceremonies. California, New Jersey, Maine and Hawaii recognize limited forms of gay partnership. State bans on gay unions were rejected by a judge in Maryland and blocked by eleven senators in Texas. Idaho passed a constitutional amendment banning gay marriage. </text> <scu uid="74" label="Canada legalized gay marriage">  <contributor label="Canada...legalized gay marriage">   <part label="Canada" summary: Hurricane Katrina which struck Florida and the U.S. Gulf Coast states of Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama is the most costly natural disaster in U.S. history. Initial insurance industry losses are estimated to be $20 billion. The Federal Emergency Management Agency expenses to date are almost $3 billion. The revised insurance losses estimate may be as high as $50 billion primarily due to damage of offshore energy sites. A Bush-Clinton Katrina Fund led by the former U.S. Presidents is accepting international donations. Qatar and Uganda have donated $100 million and $200,000 respectively. The current death count in the region is 126.    When Hurricane Katrina hit Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama on August 29, 2005 rescue crews worked frantically to save hundreds of people trapped by floodwaters. By September 8, the US death toll had reached 118. There was one reported death in Guatemala. FEMA's Katrina disaster response efforts cost $US 2.87 million as of September 6, 2005. By September 12, Swiss Reinsurance Company, estimated $US 40 billion global insured losses in the United States from Hurricane Katrina. The Emir of Qatar donated $US 100 million for US victims of Katrina. Uganda pledged $US 200,000 toward Katrina relief and rebuilding in the US.    Hurricane Katrina, one of the worst natural disasters, hit the southern part of the US on August 29, 2005. The official death toll has risen to 118. Federal Emergency Management Agency officials indicate that their costs are 2.8 billion dollars so far. Qatar donated 100 million dollars to the victims and the Ugandan government pledged 200,000 dollars toward relief and rebuilding efforts. This hurricane could cost the world's insurers up to 50 billion dollars as forecast by the British company Brit Insurance.     Hurricane Katrina hit the Gulf Coast on 29 August. By 9 September the official death toll had reached 118, including one Guatemalan woman who lived in New Orleans. Fifty other Guatemalans were missing. FEMA's mission expenses were close to $3 billion as of 6 September. Insurers, inclduing Lloyd's and Brit Insurance, estimated that their costs would reach $50 billion. Damage included offshore energy installations, as well as property damage and business interruption. Qatar was donating $100 million for the victims of the hurricane. Uganda had pladged $200,000 for relief and rebuilding. </text> <scu uid="5" label="FEMA indicates costs at 2.8 billlion ">  <contributor label="Federal Emergency Management Agency officials indicate summary: Prominent award-winning Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk was indicted for insulting the Turkish identity by comments he made to a Swiss reporter about one million Armenians massacred in Turkey during World War I. He could face up to three years in prison. The US and EU called on Turkey to drop the charges. His December 16 trial was suspended until February 7 because the court lacked a justice ministry order to proceed. The case has stirred outrage across Europe. EU officials were there to observe the trial, the outcome of which could damage the Turkey's chances of joining the EU.    Prominent Turkish novelist, Orhan Pamuk, was indicted over controversial remarks about the Armenian massacres. Pamuk is charged under Turkey's penal code which carries a jail term of more than three years for a person who "explicitly insults" the Turkish republic. The European Union (EU) warned Turkey that its prosecution of Pamuk could damage its chance of joining the EU and is a test of Turkey's commitment to freedom of expression and reforms in its law. European countries, U.S. and activist organizations have criticized Turkey's lack of democratic principles and citizen's rights.     In a Swiss newspaper interview, Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk said Turkey deliberately killed one million Armenians during WWI, triggering public outrage. He was indicted under Turkey's revised penal code for "public denigration of the Turkish identity," carrying up to 3 years in jail. Turkey says the deaths were fewer and from civil unrest, not genocide. The US, European Union, and activist organizations criticized Turkey's criminal charges for freedom of expression. The EU said Pamuk's trial would affect Turkey's EU bid. A Turkish court ruled Pamuk should be tried under old laws requiring justice ministry direct order and postponed the trial.    Orhan Pamuk went to court on 16 December for outspoken comments made during a Swiss newspaper interview about the Armenian massacres. The EU warned that the trial could affect Turkey's EU accession process because it would indicate the strength of Turkey's commitment to recent reforms guaranteeing freedom of expression. The EU Enlargement Commissioner said, "It is not Orhan Pamuk who will stand trial, but Turkey." The trial was suspended until 7 February pending a decision from the Justice Ministry. The offense had been made before the new penal code had gone into effect and therefore came under the old law. </text> <scu uid="33" label="Orhan Pamuk made contoversial comments.">  <contributor summary: Felt is in poor health and his family acknowledged that money was a factor in revealing his secret. They have agreed to the publication of a combination autobiography/biography and have signed a movie deal. L. Patrick Gray III, Acting Director of the FBI during the Watergate crisis expressed anger, shock, and betrayal at Felt's revelation. Woodward's new book reports that Felt had inadvertently revealed his role to Assistant Attorney General Stanley Pottinger while being questioned during a grand jury hearing in 1976. Pottinger told Woodward that he would not reveal his unconfirmed conclusion and he didn't thus protecting Woodward's source.    In early June a retired FBI official claimed that several other bureau officials "all since deceased" had collaborated with Felt in his role as "Deep Throat." On June 6 Mark Felt's daughter acknowledged that money played a role in the family's decision to go public. It was announced on June 15 that the Felt family had chosen a publisher for a book to be released next spring and given movie options for the Felt life story. On July 5 Bob Woodward's book "The Secret Man" appeared in stores revealing more details of Felt's role as "Deep Throat."    -----------------   D0809-B.M.100.B.D  -----------------    -----------------   D0809-B.M.100.B.F  -----------------

summary: Rader confessed to six killings on the day of his arrest, but police revealed little detail. There was much public speculation and some media reports of possible links between Rader and BTK including talk of a computer disc and DNA evidence, but investigators remained tight-lipped. On March 1 Rader was charged with 10 murders with bail set at $10 million. On April 19 Rader waived his right to a preliminary hearing at which the prosecution would explain how the police had tied Rader to the killings. This, as the DA said, "prolongs the agony of the public to know."    Rader's daughter did not turn her father in to police. Wichita investigators continue examining other killings, for possible linkage to BTK. Reportedly, DNA from Rader's daughter facilitated his identification. A computer disk in Rader's final mailing linked to his church. On March 31 Rader was charged with 10 first-degree murders. Bail was $10 million. His next court appearance was March 15. Rader waived his April 19 preliminary hearing. He would plead not guilty at arraignment May 3, and not plead insanity or plea bargain. Rader is no longer secluded from other prisoners. Kansas expected to pay $405,000 for Rader's defense.    Evidence identifying Dennis Rader as the BTK killer was found on a computer disk he mailed to a television station on February 16. Experts linked the disk to a computer at Christ Lutheran Church, where he served as the church council's president. Rader broke his 25-year silence after the Wichita Eagle published an article marking the 30th anniversary of the first BTK killings. Prosecutors cannot yet present their evidence against Rader because he waived his right to a preliminary hearing. Nearby law enforcement agencies are reinvestigating cold cases that bear similarities to the BTK slayings.    Investigators continue to examine unsolved killings over the last 31 years to determine if any can be linked to BTK. Prosecutors cannot seek the death penalty for Rader since the killings occurred before its enactment. For three decades, BTK had toyed with Wichita in letters, poems and packages. It was his most recent mailing to a TV station that helped crack the case: a computer disk traced to the computer at Rader's church. The disk along with DNA evidence led to Rader. Rader waived his right to a preliminary hearing and is expected to plead not guilty. </text> <scu uid="2" label="Rader waived his April 19 preliminary hearing">  <contributor label="Rader waived his summary: Conflicts continue between the separatist regions and Georgia. Peace processes are being disrupted by kidnappings and the suspicious accidental death of Prime Minister Zhvania as he was seeking a negotiated settlement. Saakashvili met with President Bush to discuss Georgian plans to resolve the separatist conflicts. Saakashvili and Moldovan President Voronin criticized the separatists in ex-Soviet republics. They are joining forces to seek solutions. Saakashvili calls for a new Yalta conference to consolidate democracy in Georgia and other countries. Georgian and Abkhazia separatist officials continue to negotiate peace overseen by United Nations monitors. The separatist regions still firmly maintain their independence.    On Jan. 19, 2005 South Ossetians abducted two Georgian police officers in an attempt to disrupt any peace talks. In Abkhazia the new elected president pledged to fight on for international recognition of its de facto independence. On Jan. 26 Saakashvili's offer of autonomy was immediately rejected by South Ossetia. Saakashvili then turned to the international scene presenting Georgia as a force for liberty and freedom as opposed to the separatist regions which "are the last razor-sharp splinters of the Soviet Empire." As of May 2005 Abkhazia and South Ossetia were still independent from Georgia.    Georgia refused to exchange Ossetian prisoners for Georgians captured by South Ossetia. Saakashvili asked Russia to help reunite South Ossetia and Abkhazia with Georgia. He told the Council of Europe that autonomy for South Ossetia and Abkhazia would comprise "a local government elected freely and directly, that would include an executive branch and a parliament". Georgia and Moldovia issued a joint declaration against separatist movements. Saakashvili called for a "new Yalta conference", to extend "liberty" throughout the Black Sea region. Georgia and Abkhazia met with a UN envoy to form a joint group to manage mine removal and ceasefire violations.    Saakashvili told European parliamentarians he would give more independence to separatist regions, as long as Georgia remains whole. South Ossetia immediately rejected his offer of autonomy. Peace talks broke down when two Georgian police officers were abducted and 12 Ossetians were abducted in response. Georgian and Abkhazian officials met with a UN envoy to discuss security issues and agreed to meet again in mid-June. Saakashvili discussed the issue with President Bush. He called for a new Yalta conference to extend the rule of liberty throughout the Black Sea region. Saakashvili and the Moldovan president issued a joint declaration against separatism. </text> <scu uid="1" label="Conflicts continue between the separatist regions and Georgia">  <contributor summary: New drug SR-13668 curbs AKT retroviral oncogene proteins for breast cancer. SR-16158 also treats breast cancer. The National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences' Sisters Study for breast cancer compares shared genes. Arimidex and Aromasin appear to sharply reduce breast cancer occurrence or metastasis. Oleic acid dramatically cuts expression of breast cancer precursor gene Her-2/neu and amplifies Herceptin. DNA repair deficiency strongly associates with susceptibility to breast cancer. Hypothyroidism apparently lessens chances of developing aggressive forms of breast cancer. Modern radiation therapy likely does not increase heart disease risk. Oral contraceptives likely do not increase the risk of BRAC1-associated breast cancer.    The National Health Research Institute and a pharmaceutical company are testing two medications that can treat breast cancer. One drug can curb a protein active in cancer patients and the other is less likely to trigger cardiovascular disease. A new U.S. Sister Study will investigate genetic and environmental causes of breast cancer. A new drug, aromatase inhibitor, appears to sharply reduce the chances of developing cancer in the other breast. Researchers say that olive oil may help fight breast cancer. Oral contraceptives may reduce the risk of breast cancer in high-risk groups.     Developmental drug SR-13668 curbs the oncogene protein AKT, prevalent in cancer patients; and SR-16158 reduces breast cancer patient heart disease risk. Aromatase inhibitors lessen breast cancer recurrence with fewer side effects than tamoxifen. Radiation therapy no longer carries heart disease risk. Olive oil suppresses oncogene Her-2/neu and boosts effectiveness of antibody Herceptin. Hypothyroidism and oral contraceptives reduce breast cancer risk. Sisters are being studied to investigate environmental and genetic affects on cancer risk. Deficiency in cell DNA repair-ability accelerates genetic changes leading to cancer. Protein markers in genes help predict cancer recurrence. Ductal lavage proved unreliable for detecting early cancer.    An international group is studying an aromatose inhibitor, which may replace tamoxifin. And a Taiwanese-U.S. cooperative effort is developing a new breast-cancer drug. NIH has undertaken a study of sisters to find genetic and environmental causes of the disease. Other studies are looking into the effects and effectiveness of oral contraceptives, an underactive thyroid, olive oil, a cell's ability to repair DNA, and the flushing of milk ducts. A new Dutch diagnostic tool could help some breast-cancer patients avoid unnecessary treatment. And advances in technology and techniques have now made radiation safe for breast-cancer patients. </text> <scu uid="1" label="New drug SR-13668 curbs oncogene proteins in cancer patients"> summary: Electric power networks are vulnerable to physical attacks (conventional explosives or nuclear electromagnetic pulse) and computer attacks (external or internal) against the internet-based supervisory control and data acquisition computers and networks that remotely control power generation and transmission. Recognized cyber-security improvements need to be implemented more comprehensively, especially against documented threats from Al-Qaida, and older, less secure equipment replaced. Network stability and capacity, and ensured power locally, can be improved with on-site power generation that can also increase power available to the network, such as from fuels, solar, wind, and fuel cells. Excess power can be stored as hydrogen.    Security experts warned that terrorists could unleash electromagnetic bombs that can be catastrophic. The U.S. is particularly vulnerable because it relies heavily on telecommunications and electronics. Homeland Security is being urged to set up mechanisms to stop attacks and restore power. Electric company officials have been warned that they need to focus more on cyber-security to prevent hackers from attacking U.S. electric power grids. Many nuclear power plants in the U.S. lack sirens warning of a nuclear emergency if electricity also was blacked out.     Many analysts believe the biggest threat to the power grid is from companies using older equipment that is more susceptible to attack and their reluctance to update to new computers. Former counterterrorism chief Richard Clarke opined that a sophisticated hacker could probably get into each of the three US power networks and bring down sections. Computers make the nation's infrastructure more efficient, but they also make it more vulnerable. Improved planning and additional power plants would seem to improve reliability and lessen the chance for a widespread blackout like the one in 2003. Alternative power sources could also benefit.    Electrical grid vulnerability has grown as equipment is controlled through the Internet or phone, older equipment becomes susceptible to attack, and electric companies' cybersecurity remains inadequate. Homeland Security hasn't yet assessed cyberattack threats. An electromagnetic pulse could damage electrical power systems. In 2003, fifty million Americans lost power in a blackout originating in Ohio. New York has improved power grid monitoring and is increasing in-state generation through fuel cells, windmills, and solar panels. Texas protects its grid by remaining independent. Terrorist attacks are being simulated using computer models. The 2005 Energy Bill calls for increased energy production and grid modernization. </text> <scu uid="1" label="Electrical grid control by telecommunications (internet, phone) increases summary: Special Prosecutor Patrick Fitzgerald is investigating who leaked to the press that Valerie Plame, wife of former Ambassador Joseph Wilson, was an undercover CIA agent. Wilson was a critic of the Bush administration. Administration staffers Karl Rove and I. Lewis Libby are the focus of the investigation. NY Times correspondent Judith Miller was jailed for 85 days for refusing to testify about Libby. Libby was eventually indicted on five counts: 2 false statements, 1 obstruction of justice, 2 perjury. Libby resigned immediately. He faces 30 years in prison and a fine of $1.25 million if convicted. Libby pleaded not guilty.     On October 28, 2005 Lewis Libby was indicted on two counts of making false statements, two perjury counts and obstruction of justice, by Special Prosecutor Patrick Fitzgerald's investigation into possible intentional, illegal revelation of the identify of CIA covert operative Valerie Plame. Libby's testimony was contradicted by several witnesses. No others were indicted as the grand jury was extended and Karl Rove remains under investigation. Libby will fight the charges, which have maximum penalties of 30 years and $1.25 million. Judith Miller had been jailed 85 days before testifying and surrendering notes, after Libby formally rescinded their confidential source agreement.    Special prosecutor Patrick Fitzgerald's investigation into the naming of Valerie Plame as an undercover CIA agent has led to a parade of newspersons and White House staffers before the Grand Jury. Columnist Robert Novak first revealed Plame, whose husband, former Ambassador Joseph Wilson had contradicted one of President Bush's justifications for war against Iraq. New York Times reporter Judith Miller was jailed 85 days for refusing to testify about Lewis "Scooter" Libby, Vice President's Staff Chief. WH Deputy Chief of Staff Karl Rove is under investigation. Libby resigned after being indicted on five felony counts. He has pled not guilty.    After a nearly two-year investigation in the CIA leak case, Lewis 'Scooter' Libby, Vice-President Cheney's chief of staff, was indicted on felony charges of perjury, making false statements to FBI agents, and obstruction of justice for impeding a federal grand jury. Libby resigned immediately. If convicted, he faces a maximum of 30 years in prison and a 1.25 million dollar fine. He said he plans to fight the charges. Karl Rove, President Bush's deputy chief of staff and close political advisor, was not indicted but still faces the possibility of prosecution as the investigation continues. </text> <scu uid="7" summary: India successfully launched two satellites from one rocket for the first time. To decrease costs and increase launches, India developed a universal launch pad for all future vehicles. India will host two international space conferences (planetary exploration and space law). India has signed an agreement with the European Space Agency and is talking with NASA regarding their participation in India's unmanned lunar launch. India's launch of the INSAT-4A has been delayed by the European Space Agency. Boeing cancelled their agreement with India to jointly produce communication satellites. India and Russia are collaborating on the development of a youth communication satellite.    For the first time, India is set to launch two satellites in a single mission. One is for mapping and the other for communications. India will host twin international conferences on planetary exploration and space law. Some 225 delegates including many from the US, China, Japan, Canada, France, Malaysia, Sri Lanka and Indonesia will attend. The ISRO announced the payloads from the US, Bulgaria, Germany and Britain for the Chandrayaan-1 mission. Launch of the Indian INSAT-4A communications satellite from French Guyana has been delayed. India and Russia are working on a satellite for communication between youths of the two countries.    India's space program began in 1972. It aspires to be a major space power. India developed a unique universal launching pad and plans a sophisticated propellant plant for its launch vehicle, delayed by sanctions following India's 1998 nuclear testing. India has launched eleven remote-sensing satellites and two satellites in one mission. Communication satellites include Hamsat for Ham radio and distance-learning Edusat. India and Russia plan a youth communication satellite. In 2005 ISRO hosted international conferences on planetary exploration and space law. Europe's Ariane program problems delayed launch of India's telecast and communication satellite INSAT-4A. Boeing withdrew from Indian satellite cooperation.     The Indian Prime Minister has criticized economic sanctions imposed after the 1998 nuclear weapons tests, but noted that these have not hindered India's scientific progress. India launched one rocket carrying two satellites, one for more detailed mapping, the other for home radio operators. Its first unmanned moon mission, scheduled for 2007-2008, will carry three European payloads and perhaps one U.S. payload. Meanwhile India is working with Russia to develop a satellite to enable youths in the two countries to communicate. It will host twin international conferences on planetary exploration and space law for about 225 delegates in June.  </text> <scu uid="1" label="India successfully launched two satellites from one summary: Congress passed and President Bush signed emergency legislation allowing federal review of the Schiavo case. Schiavo's parents hope to override state rulings and have their daughter's feeding tube reinserted. Federal judges refused to reverse the Florida court's ruling. Florida lawmakers refused to re-enter the case after the federal ruling. A Florida court will hear new motions per Governor Bush. However the parents' appeals for reinsertion of the feeding tube were denied. After prolonged legal debates including unprecedented Congressional intervention and five U.S. Supreme Court appeals, Terri Schiavo died 18 days after her feeding tube was removed.    Terri Schiavo died 13 days after her feeding tube was removed by order of a Florida state court judge. Her parents continued to fight to keep their daughter alive. A federal judge refused to order Terri Schiavo's feeding tube reinserted. President Bush signed an unprecedented law to avert her death. Florida lawmakers refused to intervene in her case. An appeals court and US Circuit court also ruled against her family. The US Supreme court turned aside the case of Terri Schiavo.    Michael Schiavo won a malpractice suit concerning Terri's coma in 1993. He first petitioned for feeding tube removal in 1998. After final tube removal in 2005, US District Court Judge James Whittemore refused to order reinsertion. The parents appealed to a three-judge federal appeals panel but were rebuffed. Judge Greer issued an injunction keeping the DCF and police away from Terri. Courts consistently rejected appeals related to abuse allegations or new medical diagnoses, and efforts to block Terri's cremation. The US Supreme Court again declined involvement. A federal appeals court agreed to consider a new hearing but Terri died first.    Terri Schiavo died on Thursday 31 March, thirteen days after her feeding tube was removed by court order. Her husband has requested an autopsy. In the final two weeks of Schiavo's life, at least 47 protestors were arrested and there were numerous appeals to have the tube reinserted. Efforts even included a congressional bill to shift jurisdiction from state to federal courts and President Bush's rush back from Texas to sign that bill. In Florida Governor Bush tried to get custody transferred to the Florida government. And the case bounced back and forth in state and federal courts. </text> <scu uid="38" label="Terri Schiavo dies after tube removed">  <contributor label="Terri Schiavo died 18 days after her feeding summary: The July 7 London bombing death toll is now 56, including four suicide bombers. Police identified the four and know details of their final movements. All were British of Pakistani origin. Police raided five premises in Leeds and recovered a car they expect will yield evidence. Authorities were tipped off when one bomber's mother called a help line to report him missing. ABC News reported that the alleged bomb maker behind the London attacks was arrested in Egypt. Authorities fear that a number of recent arson attacks on mosques in England may have been retaliation for the bombings.    The death toll rose to 56 and 44 victims of the bombings remain in hospitals, nine in intensive care. Four of those dead were suicide bombers who carried out the bombings. Police identified three of the bombers by name and said that all four were British of Pakistani origin. Police were able to trace the movements on CCTV of the bombers from their arrival at a carpark until just before the explosions. Armed with warrants, police raided five premises in Leeds; home to a large Muslim population of south Asian origin.    The four bombers were British of Pakistani origin and were among the 56 killed. The bombers left their homes in West Yorkshire and drove a rented a car to Luton, NW of London, where they met a fourth accomplice. Closed circuit television at King's Cross caught them all chatting, then they split up. The mother of one reported him missing after the blasts, leading to identifications and raids on five premises in Leeds, which has a large Moslem population. The alleged bomb-builder was arrested in Egypt. After the bombings, several arson attacks took place on mosques in northwest England.    As of 20 July, the death toll stood at 56, with all victims identified. Police had finished their investigations on site and moved one subway car from the underground tunnel to a police compound for further investigation.  The suspected bombers, all four of whom were killed in the explosions, were Islamic extremists. British of Pakistani origin, the four were captured on closed ciruit TV at King's Cross soon before the bomings. An additional suspect was said to have been arrested in Cairo, Egypt, on 15 July. </text> <scu uid="74" label="4 bombers">  <contributor label="four...bombers">   <part label="four" start="119" summary: Congressional hearings and an undercover probe investigating illegal steroid use in Major League Baseball and other sports continues. Baseball Commissioner Bud Selig admitted the League's policy is not strong enough and has proposed much stricter penalties. They include a 50-game suspension for the first offense and a lifetime ban for the third one. These penalties would apply to minor-league players next year. Selig also requested amphetamines be added to the banned substances. Congress has threatened to implement a testing system unless the League strengthened its policy. The Players Association has not responded to the proposed penalties.    Under pressure from Congress, Major League Baseball's players association toughened drug testing rules and penalties again for the 2006 season. Suspensions will be increased to 50 games for a first offense, 100 for a second, and a lifetime ban for the third. Congress launched an undercover probe into illegal steroid use in Major League Baseball. News of the probe surprised MLB officials. Rafael Palmeiro was suspended 10 days for a positive steroid test. He denied intentionally taking the drug. Other players with 10-day steroid test suspensions were Felix Heredia and Carlos Almanzar. New doping allegations surfaced about Barry Bonds.    Congress has launched an undercover probe into illegal steroid use in major league baseball. To highlight the problem, baseball heavy hitters Mark McGuire, Raphael Palmeiro and Sammy Sosa testified before the responsible congressional committee. In a letter to the players' union, Selig proposes a 50-game suspension for first offenders instead of the current 10-game suspension. A second offense would result in a 100-day suspension and a third, a lifetime ban. The players' union has concerns since several steroid agents stay in the blood stream for a long period. A one-time user who swore off could show positive in future testing.     Congressional investigators chided Major League Baseball leaders for being uncooperative regarding steroid use and urged star players to take public responsibility for their actions. Congress also launched an undercover probe. Players proposed strengthening the collective bargaining steroid proposal. Bud Selig proposed a 50-game suspension for first offenders, 100-game suspension for second, and lifetime ban for third. 2003 tests showed 104 steroid users. Eleven players were suspended for steroids in 2005. Felix Heredia, Carlos Almanzar and Rafael Palmeiro tested positive. BALCO's Victor Conte and James Valente, Bonds trainer Greg Anderson, and chemist Patrick Arnold were charged or sentenced concerning steroid distribution. </text> <scu uid="1" label="Congress has launched an undercover probe ">  <contributor label="Congress has launched an undercover probe into illegal steroid use in major league baseball">   <part label="Congress has launched an undercover probe into illegal steroid use in major league baseball" start="1466" end="1557"/>  </contributor>  <contributor label="Congressional hearings and an undercover probe investigating illegal steroid use in Major League Baseball">   <part label="Congressional hearings and an undercover probe investigating illegal steroid use in Major League Baseball" start="61" end="166"/>  </contributor>  <contributor label="Congress launched an undercover probe into illegal steroid use in Major League Baseball">   <part label="Congress launched an undercover probe into illegal steroid use in Major League Baseball" start="1027" end="1114"/>  </contributor>  <contributor label="Congress also launched an undercover probe">   <part label="Congress also launched an undercover probe" start="2344" end="2386"/>  </contributor> </scu> <scu uid="30" label="News of the Congressional probe surprised MLB officials">  <contributor label="Congress launched an undercover probe into illegal steroid use in Major League Baseball. summary: Three weeks after Katrina pets are still being rescued. 5,000 plus have been rescued but thousands have perished. Emergency responders are voluntarily assisting but humane societies are requesting a policy that local, state and federal responders will diligently assist with pet rescues. Representatives Lantos and Oberstar are co-sponsoring the Pets Evacuation and Transportation Standards Act to force local and state governments to create emergency evacuation plans for pets or forfeit FEMA disaster grant eligibility. Rescued animals are being fostered in prisons and other states as local shelters are overwhelmed. Unprecedented millions of dollars are being donated for pet rescue effort.    Rescue efforts continue for pets abandoned in the wake of Hurricane Katrina. Some are still found alive, but estimated tens of thousands have already died. By 10 October, some 8,000 animals have been rescued. At least 600 have been reunited with their owners. Tens of millions of dollars have been donated for Katrina animal rescue. Animals have been sent from the Lamar-Dixon shelter and another at Louisiana State University to smaller shelters, foster homes and even prisons across the country to await reunions or adoption. Lamar-Dixon will be shut down on 15 October. Petfinder.com will list pets through 15 December.    Five thousand pets have been rescued but time is running out for the rest. Many animals are sick from consuming contaminated water, garbage and carrion. LSU's Parker Coliseum (Baton Rouge) houses over a thousand rescued pets and Lamar-Dixon expo center (Gonzales) holds up to 2,000, including larger and sicker animals. Staff are from the Humane Society, US Public Health Service, FEMA, and volunteers. Pets are sent to smaller shelters, foster homes, and prisons for longer-term care. Over 600 have been reunited with owners. Rescuing people takes priority but the Humane Society and a bill in Congress urge pet evacuation also.    Tens of millions of dollars have been donated to pet charities because of Hurricane Katrina, but weeks after the storm, abandoned animals are still a major concern. It is estimated that more than 50,000 pets were left behind. Hundreds arrive at shelters every day, most suffering from at least one ailment, such as dysentery, infection, malnutrition, dehydration. Many died before they could be rescued. Local shelters are overwhelmed, so some animals are being sent to shelters and foster homes in other states. Two prisons have taken in animals, which the inmates will care for until permanent homes can be found. </text> <scu uid="277" label="Pets still being rescued">  <contributor label="pets are still summary: Scanlon pleaded guilty to conspiring to bribe a congressman and other public officials. His help was expected to be crucial in the Justice Department's wide-ranging Abramoff investigations. On Dec. 28, 2005 the Justice Department was urgently pressing Abramoff to settle fraud and bribery allegations as the investigation continued. A court date was set for Jan. 9, 2006 as Senate and criminal investigations continued. On Jan. 3 Abramoff pleaded guilty and agreed to cooperate. He agreed to provide evidence and testimony in the Justice Department's probe of corruption in Congress and executive branch agencies.    Michael Scanlon pleaded guilty to conspiring to bribe public officials and agreed to pay back over $19 million to Indian tribal clients. His possible 5-year prison sentence could be reduced should he cooperate with prosecutors. Abramoff pleaded guilty to federal conspiracy, fraud and tax evasion charges and agreed to cooperate with investigators. He did not identify officials by name. The next day he pleaded guilty to fraud and conspiracy in Florida. Panicked lawmakers, including President Bush, rushed to distance themselves from Abramoff by returning campaign money he gave them. The money is being returned or redirected to charities.    Abramoff pleaded guilty to conspiracy, fraud and tax evasion and agreed to cooperate with federal officials investing political corruption. Abramoff is also facing trial on fraud charges in Florida connected with purchasing a casino cruise chip company. In his plea agreement, Abramoff committed to making 25 million in restitution to his victims and paying 1.2 million to the IRS for tax evasion. His prison sentence could be lowered depending on assistance he provides in the corruption investigation of as many as 20 members of Congress or top congressional aides.    Abramoff's extensive corruption schemes are the subject of a Senate probe and criminal investigations by the Department of Justice and Florida prosecutors. Investigators are looking at congressmen, aides, government officials, and lobbyists, including Rep. John Doolittle, Stephen Griles, and Tony Rudy, and will follow the case wherever it leads. Scanlon pled guilty to bribery and agreed to make restitution to tribes. His help would be crucial to the Abramoff investigation. Abramoff pled guilty to conspiracy, fraud, and tax evasion and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors. Co-defendant Adam Kidan agreed to testify against Abramoff regarding fraud in a ship company purchase. </text> <scu uid="8" label="Abramoff agreed to cooperate">  <contributor label="Abramoff...agreed summary: Prior to parliamentary elections on Feb. 27, 2005 about 300 opposition activists gathered in Kyrgyzstan's capital Bishkek demonstrating in favor of democratic elections and calling for President Askar Akayev to step down at the end of his second term in October. The administration staged a counter-demonstration. After Akayev won overwhelming election victories the opposition charged the government with mass election violations, blocked roads, occupied government buildings, and held a regional governor and a district chief hostage. Akayev ordered investigation and negotiations and fired the interior minister and prosecutor general while police dispersed crowds in Bishkek.    In February 2005 rallies in Bishkek urged President Akayev to step down as promised and constitutionally required after October presidential elections, fearing a referendum to continue his reign. Akayev supporters won a landslide parliamentary victory. Opposition leaders and the European Organization for Security and Cooperation charged the elections were flawed. By March 16 opposition forces rallied, blocked roads, occupied government buildings, demanded Akayev's resignation, and took hostage a regional governor and district chief. On March 20 four policemen were beaten after police fired shots at demonstrators. Akayev ordered investigations into election fraud charges and fired the interior minister and prosecutor-general.    Kyrgyz oppositionists, fearing President Akayev might hold onto power longer than his constitutional two terms, rallied and urged him to step down. He refused, saying elections were fair, opposition leaders were unnecessarily inciting civil war, and talks were the solution to the crisis. The opposition refused to accept a landslide victory by Akayev supporters in parliamentary elections and claimed fraud. They blocked roads, occupied government buildings, and took a governor and district chief hostage. When police fired shots to dispel rioters, crowds beat four policemen to death. Akayev ordered fraud claims investigated and replaced the interior minister and prosecutor-general.    Parliamentary elections were held in Kyrgyzstan on 27 February, with presidential elections planned for October. Akayev supporters won a landslide victory in most areas, but both opposition leaders and western observers cited mass violations. Run-off parliamentary elections were held in many regions on 13 March. The opposition was defeated but refused to accept the results and demanded Akayev's resignation. Even before the election, opposition leaders had been calling for Akayev to step down as President at the end of October in accordance with the constitution. But Akayev refused to resign or to annul the election results. </text> <scu uid="64" label="Akayev won a landslide parliamentary victory.">  <contributor label="Akayev won overwhelming election summary: The Lefkow murder investigation continues. FBI Director Mueller testified to lawmakers that the case will be solved. Bart Ross confessed to the Lefkow murders in his suicide note. Several years ago Judge Lefkow had dismissed Ross' billion dollar medical malpractice suit. DNA evidence gathered at the murder scene matched Ross' DNA. Gun shells found at the suicide location along with the note recounting details only the killer would know point to Ross as the likely killer. No evidence has been found linking Ross to the Hale supremacist group. Authorities will not close the case before ballistic results are completed.    The Lefkow murder investigation took a surprising turn when Bart Ross committed suicide at a traffic stop on March 9, leaving a handwritten confession in his car. Later that day, a local TV station receive a typed suicide letter, dated February 13, which included a hit list of judges, lawyers and doctors and a handwritten account of the Lefkow killings. Ross felt he was a medical malpractice victim and spent over a decade unsuccessfully pursuing lawsuits. Judge Lefkow, who recently ruled against Ross, was his primary target the day of the killings. DNA evidence confirm he was the killer.    Bart Ross, 57, was pulled over by police in a Milwaukee suburb for a defective taillight. Ross immediately committed suicide with a shot to his head. In his van was a letter describing how after treatment for mouth cancer left him disfigured, Judge Lefkow and others ruined his life by dismissing his medical malpractice suit. He vowed to kill them. On February 28th he hid in a Lefkow closet waiting for the judge, but her family found him first so he killed them instead. DNA from a cigarette butt in the home matched Ross's and he resembled a composite sketch.    The killer of Judge Lefkow's husband and mother, Bart Ross, killed himself on 9 March with a single shot to the head when he was stopped for a routine traffic violation. In his van was a suicide note linking him to the murders. He had pursued a decade-long malpractice suit over severe disfigurement resulting from treatment for a cancerous jaw, a suit Lefkow had dismissed a number of years ago. He wrote that she was "No. 1 to kill" because she had "finished me off." He had a hit list of 25 other judges, lawyers, and doctors. </text> <scu uid="5" label="Bart Ross committed suicide">  <contributor label="Bart Ross committed suicide">   <part label="Bart Ross summary: The funeral service for Pope John Paul II was held Friday, April 8. Mourners interrupted the funeral service by calling for sainthood for Pope John Paul II now. Friday was declared a national day of mourning in Poland, home of his birth, and in Malawi, South Africa. In Krakow live images of the service were telecast from Rome. Monuments will be erected throughout Poland to honor the late Pope. One monument was inaugurated immediately on Saturday in the Rakowicki cemetery, Krakow where members of his family are buried. Cardinals will begin the conclave to elect a successor on April 18.      The world said a final farewell to Pope John Paul II at his solemn funeral on April 8. A huge throng of mourners applauded as his coffin was carried from Saint Peter's Basilica and placed before the altar. Dignitaries stood in respect. The requiem mass followed centuries of solemn ritual. He was interred in the crypt of Saint Peter's Basilica. The late Pope's native Poland declared a national holiday. Hundreds of thousands of mourners gathered to watch the televised funeral. Hundreds gathered for interfaith prayers at a Warsaw synagogue. Cardinals will meet on April 18 to elect a new pontiff.    The funeral ceremony for Pope Paul II began in Saint Peter's Square in front of a huge throng of mourners including state leaders who applauded as the coffin was placed on the altar. In Tokyo, Japan, diplomats and government officials joined 1,500 Catholics in a mass mourning for the pope. Several hundred people of all faiths prayed at a Warsaw synagogue. The Grand Rabbi of Poland led the ecumenical prayer. A monument to Pope Paul II was inaugurated in a Krakow cemetery, where the late pope's family is buried.    An open-air requiem mass was held for Pope John Paul II in St. Peter's Square from 10am-12:30 pm on Friday. As the mass ended, lengthy applause broke out from the enormous throng of mourners. The body, in a plain cypress wooden coffin, was laid to rest in the crypt of St.Peter's Basilica following the funeral. On Saturday a monument was unveiled at the Krakow cemetary where the pope's family is buried. summary: After 18 months the International Astronomical Union has still not determined the criteria for planethood. Pluto's eventual status will also define new space objects. However the data from the Pluto space probe in 2015 will come too late to settle this argument. Recent discovery of two additional moons around Pluto complicate the issue. The diameter of Pluto and UB313 is about 1,380 and 1,800 miles respectively and both have methane ice on their surfaces. Proposed definitions based on size or gravitational pull either include or exclude Pluto and UB313. The scientific deadlock at the Union will not be resolved quickly.    A committee of the International Astronomical Union (IAU) is considering the question of planethood of Pluto and 2003 UB313 (Xena). Both might be called "minor planets" or could be considered KBOs. NASA's Hubble Space telescope strengthened Pluto's claim to planethood by finding its second and perhaps third moon. On Jan 20, 2006 NASA launched its New Horizon spacecraft to explore Pluto and the Kuiper Belt which it is scheduled to reach in July 2015. Meanwhile German astronomers determined that the diameter of 2003 UB313 is 1800 miles compared to Pluto's 1380. The IAU committee continues to deliberate.    Debate continues over what constitutes a planet. Some astronomers say a planet should have a diameter greater than 2,000 kilometers (both Pluto and UB313 do). Another suggestion is roundness: this would include these two and likely several others yet unknown. Another possible definition is that a planet must gravitationally dominate its surroundings, which would exclude Pluto and UB313. Pluto became more interesting when the Hubble telescope discoverd that Pluto had not just one but three moons. Scientific interest in Pluto and Kuiper Belt objects led to the New Horizons spacecraft mission: a nine year trip to Pluto and beyond.     Scientists debate redefining "planet" or retiring the term. KBO 2003 UB313, discovered by Michael E. Brown, was confirmed by surface heat emanations to be 30 percent larger than Pluto. Both have surface methane ice. If Pluto is a planet, 2003 UB313 should be too. The Hubble Space Telescope showed two more small moons orbiting Pluto, 30-100 miles in diameter. Pluto and its large moon Charon, close physically and in size, may be a binary planet system orbiting a center mass between them. At least four KBOs have known moons. Pluto would be the first KBO to have multiple satellites.  </text> <scu uid="1" label="The International Astronomical Union has not defined "planet".">  <contributor label="After 18 months the International Astronomical Union has still not determined the criteria for planethood">   <part label="After 18 months the International Astronomical Union has still not determined the criteria for planethood" start="61" end="166"/>  </contributor>  <contributor label="A committee of the International Astronomical Union (IAU) is considering the question of planethood">   <part label="A committee of the International Astronomical Union (IAU) is considering the question of planethood" start="745" end="844"/>  </contributor>  <contributor label="Debate continues over what constitutes a planet">   <part label="Debate continues over what constitutes a planet" start="1411" end="1458"/>  </contributor>  <contributor label="Scientists debate redefining "planet" or retiring the term">   <part label="Scientists debate redefining "planet" or retiring the term" start="2105" end="2163"/>  </contributor> </scu> <scu uid="2" label="Pluto's eventual status will also define 2003 UB313's.">  <contributor label="Pluto's eventual status will also define new space objects">   <part label="Pluto's eventual status will also define new space objects" start="168" end="226"/>  </contributor>  <contributor label="Pluto and 2003 UB313 (Xena). summary: In July 2005 ornithologists Richard Prum, Mark Robbins and Jerome Jackson, submitted a paper questioning the sufficiency of the evidence for the ivory-billed woodpecker's rediscovery. They withdrew their paper after hearing audio recordings of calls and raps reportedly matching 1930's recordings of the bird. But they and others remained skeptical. In December over 100 researchers and volunteers began an intensive six-month search across 500,000 acres of Arkansas wetlands seeking definitive evidence of the bird. A local town benefited from bird watching tourists. In January 2006 Jackson published an article saying claims for proof of the bird's existence constitute "faith-based ornithology".    Biologists question evidence in sightings of rare ivory-billed woodpecker. The issue is whether four seconds of fuzzy videotape is an ivory-billed or pileated woodpecker. Recordings of the ivory-billed woodpecker's distinctive double-rap sounds convinced scientists of this bird's existence. A crew from Cornell Lab and its partner agencies will train 100 volunteers for a six-month search of 500,000 acres in the eastern Arkansas wetlands. An ivory-bill specialist criticized the finding saying the bird's existence hasn't been confirmed and the videotape shows a pileated woodpecker.    Three biologists questioned reported sightings and a fuzzy videotape as sufficient evidence that the ivory-billed woodpecker is not extinct. However, more recent audio recordings of calls and distinctive double-rap sounds removed their doubts. Cornell ornithologists made 17,000 hours of recordings near the Cache and White rivers in Arkansas. The discovery raised concerns that this habitat could be inundated with bird watchers. Cornell will train 100 volunteers for a six-month search for the bird. Federal authorities have provided $10.2M toward the effort and the Nature Conservancy has bought 18,000 acres of Big Woods habitat to set aside for the bird.    The rediscovery of the ivory-billed woodpecker was challenged in late April, almost three months after its announcement. Three biologists planned to publish a paper saying that the evidence was insufficient, a conclusion also reached by Sibley, author of well-known field guides. But two of the scientists were given recordings based on 18,000 hours of audio and, on the basis of this "new evidence," they withdrew their challenge and the paper was not published. In January 2006, however, the third biologist voiced the strongest criticism to date, saying that he was still not convinced. The search continues. </text> <scu uid="1" label="In July 2005 three biologists submitted a paper questioning the evidence for the rediscovery of the ivory-billed woodpecker.">  <contributor summary: Christine A. Gregoire was sworn in as the new governor on Jan. 12, 2005. In the first action on Dino Rossi's lawsuit to oust Gregoire the Judge declared that his courtroom and not the Democratic-controlled legislature was the proper forum to investigate the election. The case was scheduled to go to trial May 23. Although Democrats acknowledged human errors in vote counting, they vigorously denied Republican charges of fraud. The lawsuit was dismissed on June 6 for lack of evidence and Rossi did not appeal to the Supreme Court.    Christine Gregoire's inauguration as Washington's governor occurred amid a legal challenge by Republican candidate Rossi. Chelan County Superior Court Judge John Bridges ruled that his court rather than the state legislature would investigate the election. The judge ruled that before ordering a new election or declaring Rossi the winner, Republicans would need to prove Rossi received more votes than Gregoire after supposed illegal votes were deducted. Bridges noted that the only proven illegal votes had been for Rossi. Five months after the inauguration, Judge Bridges dismissed the Republican lawsuit. After that ruling, Rossi ended his legal effort to remove Gregoire.    Gregoire was sworn in as governor and proceeded to govern as if elected by landslide, imposing taxes and improving roads. Rossi sued for a revote in Republican-leaning, rural Chelan County, claiming illegal votes by felons and ballot-box stuffing. Most Washingtonians opposed a revote. Constitutional language on contested races was ambiguous. Judge John E. Bridges heard the case without a jury. He dismissed the lawsuit because Rossi's lawyers failed to meet their burden of proof. Most of the proved illegal votes by felons were for Rossi. Rossi ended his efforts to remove Gregoire, who was certified as governor-elect in June 2005.    Democrat Christine Gregoire was sworn in as governor of Washington state on 12 January after an extremely close election. The Republicans sued to overturn the gubernatorial election, charging election fraud. A judge dismissed the lawsuit on 6 June, asserting that there were human errors but no fraud, and Republican Dino Rossi decided to end his 5-month legal fight. Gregoire was declared the winner in late June by the Washington Secretary of State. Meanwhile, by the end of the month Rossi vowed to continue his fight and called for a new vote. </text> <scu uid="55" label="Gregoire sworn in as governor">  <contributor label="Christine A. summary: Relief for the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami victims continues. More than $10 billion has been pledged by 42 countries and individuals. Debt relief and loans are also being offered. Concerts, telethons, and charity auctions are among the methods being used to solicit donations. President Bush made a personal contribution of $10,000. Bush recruited Former Presidents Clinton and Bush, his father, to lead fundraising efforts in the U.S. President Bush signed a law permitting U.S. taxpayers to deduct contributions to tsunami relief in January 2005 from their 2004 returns. The Canadian government will match all private donations to approved aid agencies.    Financial contributions for Asian Tsunami relief had exceeded $10 billion by Jan. 12, 2005. Governmental contributions passed $8 billion while private gifts exceeded $2 billion. The United Nations announced that it has secured aid commitments worth $717 million. Governmental contributions were led by Japan with $74m. and Germany at $68m. The outstanding organizational contributor was World Vision Australia which had raised $15.3m through a telethon. Individual contributors were led by a Canadian couple Kroum and Eva Pindoff who gave $4.1m through the Canadian Red Cross which will be matched by the Canadian government to total $8.2m.    Governments have pledged over eight billion dollars in aid for countries hit by the Asian tsunami and private contributions have added over two billion dollars. Countries pledging aid include: Japan, Britain, Germany, Norway, European Commission, the US, Canada, Sweden, Denmark, Russia, China, Australia and Finland. Money raised from ticket sales for a Canadian TV broadcast will go to tsunami relief. An Australian telethon and Melbourne cricket match raised money for relief. Two Chinese banks have made large contributions. Individuals making large contributions include actress Sandra Bullock, President George Bush, a Chinese couple and Kroum and Eva Pindoff, a Canadian couple.    As of 12 January, donations and pledges continued to pour in for tsunami relief. Government donations from 42 countries exceeded $8 billion. Australia had raised more per capita than any other country, including donations made through a telethon and a pop concert telecast simultaneously on all three TV networks. The UN had aid commitments for $717 million for emergency relief, with Japan as the major contributor at $250 million. Private donations reached more than $2 billion, the largest from a Canadian couple, who gave $4.1 million, which the Canadian government will match. </text> <scu uid="2" label="Government donations
