summary: 23 countries recently met in Greenland to encourage governments to act on global warming instead of arguing. Worldwide, countries are agreeing that the U.N. Kyoto Protocol, which commits 39 nations to reduce greenhouse gases, is not enough. Infrastructure in Russia is being damaged due to the melting permafrost including airports, gas pipelines and railways. Wildlife including polar bears, reindeer, seals, and fish are threatened as well as many plant species. Fishing zones are disappearing. Shipping lanes are at risk. The Arctic and Antarctic of today will be radically changed within the next century if action is not taken worldwide.    Arctic sea ice is melting faster. Its area is down 20% and it all could disappear this century. Thinning sea ice threatens extinction of polar bears. Less ice reflects less sunlight, warming the planet, leading to more ice melt and sea-level rise. Greenland and Antarctic ice shelf melting will double the estimated global sea level rise to 1 meter. Arctic permafrost thaw releases warming greenhouse gases, which will increase permafrost melting up to 11 feet deep by 2100. Greenland's ice fishing season has shortened. Lake areas doubled. Glaciers Sermeg, Sermilik, and Kangerdlugssuag melted faster. Alaska's Columbia glacier also melted faster.    Climate change could thaw the top 11 feet of permafrost in most areas of the Northern Hemisphere by 2100 altering ecosystems across Alaska, Canada and Russia according to a US study. If this occurs, considerable amounts of greenhouse gases could be released into the atmosphere, which could amplify global warming. However, another researcher disagrees that the thaw would be so large. He states that Alaska's permafrost won't melt that fast or deep. A group of countries, which fringe the Artic waters, met to discuss measures to reduce greenhouse emissions.     Several international meetings have been held to address the issues of global warming and climate change. There continues to be disagreement on whether or not this is the effect of human activity, although scientists agree that something has changed radically and that there are few other explanations. New satellite photos show that Arctic ice is melting faster than before and that air temperatures are rising sharply. And two explorers working with Greenpeace could not complete a trip from Siberia to the North Pole because of the effects of rising temperatures, including broken ice, strong currents, and heavy rainfall. </text> <scu uid="69" label="23 countries met">  <contributor label="23 countries...recently...met">   <part label="23 countries" start="61" end="73"/>   <part label="met" start="83" end="86"/>   <part label="recently" start="74" end="82"/>  </contributor>  <contributor label="A group of countries, which fringe the Artic waters, met to discuss measures to reduce greenhouse emissions">   <part label="A group of countries, which fringe the Artic waters, met to discuss measures to reduce greenhouse emissions" start="1918" end="2025"/>  </contributor> </scu> <scu uid="70" label="23 countries met in Greenland">  <contributor label="23 countries...met...in Greenland">   <part label="23 countries" start="61" end="73"/>   <part label="met" start="83" end="86"/>   <part label="in Greenland" start="87" end="99"/>  </contributor> </scu> <scu uid="71" label="23 countries met to encourage governments to act on global warming">  <contributor label="23 countries...met...to encourage governments...to act on global warming...instead of arguing">   <part label="23 countries" start="61" end="73"/>   <part label="met" start="83" end="86"/>   <part label="to encourage governments" start="100" end="124"/>   <part label="instead of arguing" start="150" end="168"/>   <part label="to act on global warming" start="125" end="149"/>  </contributor> </scu> <scu uid="78" label="countries agree Kyoto Protocol not enough">  <contributor label="Worldwide...countries are agreeing...U.N. summary: Syria's withdrawal of forces from Lebanon, required by UN Resolution 1559, Sept. 2, 2004, was not satisfied by Syria's proposal on Feb. 24, 2005 to pull back into eastern Lebanon. The U.N. Chief, supported by Egypt, Saudi Arabia, the U.S., France and Russia, called for full withdrawal. On March 5 the Syrian President promised pullback to the border. A top UN envoy on March 12 demanded a full withdrawal by April 30, a position supported by the European Union. By April 26 withdrawal was under way and the UN had sent a team to verify whether it was complete.    UN Security Council Resolution 1559 mandated withdrawal of "foreign forces" (Syria's troops and intelligence agents) from Lebanon. After the February 14, 2005 assassination of former Lebanon Prime Minister Hariri, Anon told Syria to withdraw before April, threatening sanctions. Egypt and Saudi Arabia asked Syria to withdraw by April 30, under the 1989 Taif Accord. Lebanon's pro-Syria government resigned March 1. On March 12 Anon sent envoy Roed-Larsen to Syria with an ultimatum. Syria pledged to withdraw all troops. EU Foreign Ministers asked Syria to rapidly implement its pledge.     The February assassination of former Lebanon Prime Minister Hariri put Syria under renewed pressure from the international community to abide by U.N. Security Council Resolution 1559 and withdraw its troops from Lebanon. The US, France and other European Union nations urged Syria to comply. Egypt and Saudi Arabia encouraged Syria to withdraw its troops by the U.N. deadline of April 30. Faced with a U.N. ultimatum, on April 3 Syria pledged to remove all troops and intelligence agents by April 30. The U.N. sent a team of inspectors to verify whether the withdrawal was complete at the end of April.    The killing of Lebanon's former PM Rafiq Hariri renewed calls for Syria to abide by UN Security Council Resolution 1559 and end its domination of Lebanon. Nine council members voted for the resolution, six abstained. Egypt and Saudi Arabia are trying to persuade Syria to accept a timetable for withdrawal of its troops. The US and France have been leading calls for Syria's withdrawal. The European Union called for a precise timetable for withdrawal. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan said that withdrawal must be handled with care. Under mounting pressure, Syria has withdrawn 4,000 of its 14,000 troops. </text> <scu uid="49" label="Demands for Syria's full withdrawal from Lebanon">  <contributor label="The U.N. summary: On the night of Nov. 9, 2005 the level of violence throughout France showed the first signs of abating. More than 11,500 police and gendarmes in 300 cities and towns had been mobilized. Residents, police and firefighters suffered one death and more than 115 injuries. More than 7500 vehicles were torched. Although the riots were ignited by the accidental electrocution death of two teenagers, President Chirac acknowledged that France must confront inequalities and discrimination among its African and Muslim minorities that fueled the unrest. On Nov. 14 emergency powers were extended for three months.    After long police absence, Sarkozy's October 19 declaration of "war without mercy" on violent suburbs fueled the riots starting October 27. On November 8, France declared a state of emergency, and offered social assistance. By November 11, 118 residents, police, firefighters, and foreign journalists were injured, with $US 235 million total damage. By November 13, torched vehicles exceeded 8,000 and arrests exceeded 2,200. Vehicle torchings and arrests, respectively, November 1 - 12 were: 180/34, ?/?, 517/78, 897/250, 1300/349, 1408/395, 1173/330, 617/?, 482/?, 325/?, 384/162, 315/161. (Before the riots, 3,500 vehicles burned monthly nationwide.) France extended emergency powers on November 14.    With a state of emergency declaration, overnight curfews, and a public meetings ban, violent riots around Paris and throughout France steadily abated. The situation markedly improved by the 18th night. The French cabinet extended emergency police powers for three months to ensure an end to the riots. Some 300 towns and cities were affected and around 11,500 anti-riot forces were mobilized. Damages and casualties were considerable. Over 115 citizens, police officers and firefighters were injured, as were three foreign reporters. A rioter lost a hand throwing a Molotov cocktail. Over 7,500 vehicles were torched and dozens of buildings destroyed.    Rioting and unrest spread to some 300 areas across France. The government declared a state of emergency but left it to local authorities to enact curfews or other measures. Many areas did impose curfews but Paris only banned public meetings. Police were mobilized and made hundreds of arrests. Most rioters are young Arab and black residents who complain of economic misery and discrimination. They burned hundreds of vehicles and other acts of arson. President Chirac acknowledged that France must confront the inequalities and discrimination that fueled the unrest. For years, police had warned that immigrant-dominated slums were about to explode.  </text> <scu uid="40" label="Vehicles torched">  <contributor label="They burned hundreds of vehicles">   <part summary: Defendants argued intelligent design is science, not religion, because its testable "irreducible complexity" claim implies an intelligent designer but not necessarily God. One board member lied to hide that a church bought the "Pandas" books. On December 20, 2005 the judge ruled that the board's action violates the constitution. "Intelligent design is "a religious view, a mere re-labeling of creationism". He excoriated board members for lying in their testimony, for not bothering to understand intelligent design and for the "breathtaking inanity of the Board's decision". The ruling is binding only in one Pennsylvania district. Dover will pay large legal fees.    For three weeks plaintiffs in the Kitzmiller vs. Dover Area School District trial presented expert witnesses who testified that intelligent design does not meet the definition of science because it cannot be proved or disproved. For the next three weeks, the defense called witnesses who testified that intelligent design is not based on religious beliefs, but on observable, physical evidence from nature. The judge ruled that compelling teachers to present intelligent design as an alternative explanation to evolution violates the Constitution. Dover residents ousted all eight school board members running for re-election who put their town in the global spotlight.    At the trial, a biochemistry professor at Lehigh and lawyers at the Thomas More Law Center testified for teaching intelligent design as a credible scientific theory. Scientists testifying for the parents dismissed intelligent design because it can't be tested by experiment. A federal judge ruled that teaching intelligent design as an alternative explanation to evolution violates the constitution. He wrote that the overwhelming evidence established that intelligent design is a religious view and not a scientific theory and its inclusion in public schools violates the separation of church and state.    Both sides agreed to a bench trial without a jury, common in First Amendment cases where arguments are about legal rather than factual issues. At the trial, board members said they wanted to "encourage critical thinking." However, the parents presented evidence the board's purpose was religious and the intelligent design statement was a compromise after they could not teach creationism. The trial judge ruled that compelling biology teachers to present intelligent design as an alternative explanation to evolution violates the constitution. Four days after final arguments in the case, Dover residents ousted all eight school board members running for re-election. </text> <scu uid="6" label="Trial was named Kitzmiller vs. Dover Area School summary: Airbus announced it is two to six months behind its promised A380 delivery schedule. Airlines are seeking millions in damages contractually agreed upon for delays. Airbus raised the price to approximately $292 million. A wing failure during testing may delay the A380's safety certification. The U.S. is investigating whether the jet will need special safety regulations due to the turbulence it generates. 33 were injured in an emergency evacuation drill. 873 passengers and crew exited under 80 seconds and the A380 passed the test. Airbus plans to deliver the first two jets to Singapore Airlines by the end of 2006.    By June 1, 2005 customizing A380s for 15 different client requirements, notably for different passenger entertainment systems, had delayed deliveries up to 8 months, risking millions in penalties. The first A380 delivery (to Singapore) slid from early to late 2006. With 159 orders from 16 customers and 100 options, production fell behind demand, raising the price to U.S. $292 million. Possible A380 air turbulence problems potentially requiring ICAO rule-making, a wing load test failure and passenger injuries during a simulated evacuation did not slow deliveries. By 2006 20 airports will be A380-ready; 38 by 2008; 60 by 2010.    The A380 has passed its emergency evacuation test, an important component toward the super jumbo's official certification for commercial flights. Airbus executives say the company will have to pay millions in compensation for late deliveries of the A380. Production problems rather than safety or quality issues have caused the delays. Airbus has 159 firm orders and 10 options from 16 clients. The US is studying the potential for turbulence generated by the A380 reflecting safety precautions.      In 2005 the A380 was six months behind schedule and owed millions in buyer compensation. Customized cabins and entertainment system installation problems caused delays. France called unreasonable a US-proposed safety review to determine whether A380 turbulence would require greater distances around the plane. Airbus raised the A380's price by $10 million. A wing ruptured during a February 2006 stress test but the plane qualified in emergency evacuation, an important step towards certification. Airbus was approaching its break-even point of 250 plane sales. Twenty airports would be ready for A380s in 2006, with Singapore Airlines being first to fly the plane.  </text> <scu uid="1" label="A380 behind delivery schedule">  <contributor label="Airbus summary: Sudan and Darfur's two main rebel groups, the Sudan Liberation Army and the Justice and Equality Movement, signed a ceasefire in Ndjamena in April, 2004. On October 6, the UK prime minister visited Sudan to discuss Darfur. AU-lead peace talks in Abuja between those Darfur rebels and Sudan ran August 23 through September 17, reconvened October 21, but were suspended by the AU on October 27. Libya hosted a "mini-summit" with leaders of Sudan, Egypt, Nigeria, Chad and the JEM in Tripoli on October 17-21; SLA declined. EU and AU officials met October 23-24 in Khartoum with the Sudan President.     Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi, called for a Darfur mini-summit to be held on October 21, 2004 in Sirte, Libyan. Gadhafi invited the presidents of Sudan, Egypt, Chad, Nigeria and the leaders of Darfur's two rebel groups. Talks between Darfur rebels and the Sudanese government were held in Abuja, Nigeria in August and September 2004. The next round of talks will be held as part of the Darfur mini-summit, which was switched to Tripoli. This was done to obtain cooperation from neighboring countries, which is crucial to lasting peace.    Libya and the African Union have invited Sudanese President Omar al-Beshir to attend a mini-summit in Libya on October 21st with Chad, Egypt and Nigeria. Originally set for Sirte, Libya, the meeting was later shifted to Tripoli. Earlier talks had been held in Abuja in August and September. The Sudanese Liberation Army would not attend the Libyan meeting. British PM Tony Blair planned to meet in Addis Abbaba, Ethiopia with Nigerian President and current AU chairman Olusegun Obasanjo. Peace talks between the Sudanese government and rebel groups in Abuja, Nigeria, adjourned but would resume after Ramadan.    The latest Darfur peace talks opened on 24 October in Abuja, Nigeria. Sponsored by the African Union, the meetings between Khartoum and the Darfur rebels were expected to last at least three weeks. The meetings were adjourned on Wednesday morning so that AU mediators could prepare a document for discussion that same afternoon. An earlier AU summit in Abuja concerning the Darfur crisis collapsed on 18 September when the two sides disagreed on security issues. Foreign ministers from Libya, Sudan, Egypt, Nigeria, and Chad had met in Libya on 16 October to prepare for that summit. </text> <scu uid="68" label="Ceasefire was signed by Sudan Liberation Army "> summary: Debates continue in an effort to reach a compromise on Senate procedures for judicial nominees. Democrats feel the re-nomination of judges found unacceptable to them unprecedented. Both parties are using Brown's race, African American, in support of their opposite positions on her. Black members of Congress oppose Brown's confirmation. A compromise agreement was reached. Democrats will oppose any filibuster attempts regarding Brown's confirmation but the filibuster rules will remain unchanged. The successful cloture vote to end debate on Brown will now permit an up-or-down confirmation vote. After a 2 year delay Justice Brown was confirmed by a 56-43 vote.    As the Senate debated the issue of filibustering judicial nominations, a bipartisan group of centrist senators kept working on possible compromise solutions. On May 23, 14 moderate senators announced an agreement under which Democrats would vote to end debate on three nominations including Brown's, while Republicans agreed to oppose any attempt to change filibuster rules. On June 6 debate on  Brown's nomination opened with Republicans praising her great talent while Democrats deemed her an extreme conservative ideologue. On June 8, 10 Democrats joined Republicans to close debate and the Senate voted 56-43 to confirm Brown.    Just prior to the successful May 24, 2005 cloture vote for the first judicial nominee under Senate consideration (Pricilla Owen for U.S. Appeals Court 5th Circuit) 14 moderate Senators confirmed their mutual pact to: vote for cloture in judicial confirmations, except in "extraordinary circumstances"; not change filibuster rules; and vote for cloture for three less contentious federal judicial nominees, including Brown and Owen. On June 6, the Senate opened debate on Brown's confirmation. On June 7, 10 Democrats joined in the successful vote for cloture for Brown. On June 8, the Senate approved Brown's judicial appointment by 56-43.    Averting a showdown, Senate Democrats and Republicans finally reached a compromise which cleared the way for confirmation votes on California Supreme Court Justice Janice Rogers Brown's nomination to the US District Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. After stalling Brown's nomination with a 2-year filibuster threat, Democrats agreed to vote for cloture, ending the debate on June 7. Republicans agreed not to force a change in the application of Senate filibuster rules by the so-called nuclear option. On June 8, Janice Rogers Brown won confirmation. </text> <scu uid="1" label="Senate debated the issue of filibustering judicial nominations">  <contributor label="the Senate debated the issue of summary: During his first 15 months as a U.S. Senator (Jan 2005-Mar 2006), Obama became better known and more widely admired. His book "Dreams From My Father" became a bestseller. On the senate floor he demonstrated willingness to work on a bipartisan basis on foreign and domestic issues. In party affairs he continued his successes as a fundraiser. One political analyst said, "The party needs him and for all I know, the nation needs him." Some compared him to John F. Kennedy but Doris Kearns Goodwin warned there were also similarities to William J. Bryan.    Barack Obama is the 5th black Senator in U.S. history. In 2005 he received Harvard Law School's highest award, at which he criticized the Katrina debacle. He published a Time magazine article about President Lincoln. He criticized the Bush administration and called for troop withdrawal from Iraq. In 2006 he met with the Foreign Minister in Israel. First term Senator Obama and senior Senator McCain worked on ethics reform, had a public spat, and made nice. As Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee Vice Chairman, he helped raise $6.5 million. He won a Grammy for his audio book "Dreams of My Father".    Barak Obama was received like a rock star and hero at a luncheon where he was bestowed the Harvard Law School Association Award. Obama took a 10-day tour of the Middle East that included visits to Iraq, Kuwait, Jordan, Palestinian territories, and Israel. He met with Israeli Foreign Minister Shalom and conveyed to him the United States' support for Israel as its leader Ariel Sharon lay stricken by a stroke. Obama won a Grammy Award for his readings of his autobiographical book Dreams From My Father, which became a best seller as he became a rising political star.    At a sold-out luncheon for black alumni at Harvard Law School, Obama was introduced as a rock star and hero. He urged the nearly 1,000 attendees to take personal responsibility in combating urban poverty. In 2005 Obama called for troop reduction in Iraq and a timeframe for phased withdrawal. He visited Israel and met with the Prime Minister and mended a rift with John McCain over lobbying reform. He won the Best Spoken Word Grammy for his autobiographical "Dreams From My Father". He became an important fundraiser for fellow democrats and tweaked the press for its fawning coverage of him. </text> <scu uid="62" label="His book "Dreams From My Father" attracted attention.">  <contributor label="His book "Dreams From My Father" became a bestseller">   <part label="His book "Dreams From My Father" became a bestseller" start="178" end="230"/>  </contributor>  <contributor label="He won a Grammy for his audio book "Dreams of My Father"">   <part label="He won a Grammy for his audio book "Dreams of My Father"" start="1220" end="1276"/>  </contributor>  <contributor label="Obama won a Grammy Award for his readings of his autobiographical book Dreams From My Father, which became a best seller as he became a rising political star">   <part label="Obama won a Grammy Award for his readings of his autobiographical book Dreams From My Father, which became a best seller as he became a rising political star" start="1746" end="1903"/>  </contributor>  <contributor label="He won the Best Spoken Word Grammy for his autobiographical "Dreams From My Father"">   <part label="He won the Best Spoken Word Grammy for his autobiographical "Dreams From My Father"" start="2362" end="2445"/>  </contributor> </scu> <scu uid="63" label="He called for troop withdrawal from Iraq">  <contributor label="In 2005 Obama called for troop reduction in Iraq and a timeframe for phased withdrawal">   <part label="In 2005 Obama called for troop reduction in Iraq and a timeframe for phased withdrawal" start="2167" end="2253"/>  </contributor>  <contributor label="called for troop withdrawal from Iraq">   <part label="called for troop withdrawal from Iraq" start="930" end="967"/>  </contributor> </scu> <scu uid="64" label="He was an important fundraiser for democrats. summary: In response to a call from the Institute of Medicine for a program against childhood obesity, there has been some action. One children's TV network introduced a Saturday afternoon message encouraging children to go out and play. Some schools have expanded physical education programs, yanked junk foods from vending machines and reduced fat in cafeteria food. At least one YMCA has introduced a fitness room designed for pre-teens. Congress has considered legislation to control advertising to children and Kraft Foods promised to stop TV advertising of certain products considered unhealthy to children under 12.    To combat childhood obesity in the US, schools are removing unhealthy food from vending machines, reducing the fat in lunches, and requiring more physical education. New Hampshire is instituting twice-yearly weigh-ins for students. Children's hospitals have weight management programs and a YMCA has a kid-friendly fitness room. Efforts are being made to regulate advertising to young children. Manufacturers offer cereals low in sugar and salt with more vitamins and whole grains. US Cabinet secretaries and children's television networks are promoting healthier lifestyles for children. In New Zealand, schools added a mandatory extra hour of physical activity for students every week.    Scientists say reversing childhood obesity requires wide-ranging efforts. Less time should be spent in front of the computer and television. Schools should remove junk food from vending machines and reduce the fat in cafeteria lunches. Experts recommend reducing sugar consumption. Changes need to be made in food labeling and advertising as well as more school and community recreational facilities and physical education programs. Trainers can help kids who don't enjoy organized sports or who are embarrassed doing active things with fitter kids.      Measures to fight childhood obesity include less time at the TV and computer, changes in food labeling and advertising, more school and community physical education programs and education to help children make better choices. The children's network Nickelodeon is encouraging children to go outside and play. They have also awarded grants to schools to expand physical play. Kraft  will stop TV ads of products unhealthy for children. New Zealand has ordered schools to ensure children take extra physical education. Schools in New Hampshire and Rhode Island have removed junk food and reduced fat in cafeteria lunches. </text> <scu uid="37" label="Schools expanding physical education programs">  <contributor summary: Cunningham resigned from Congress on Nov. 28, 2005 after pleading guilty to taking at least $2.4 million in bribes to help four unnamed co-conspirators win defense contracts. The FBI continued its investigation of defense contractors. On Feb. 18 prosecutors recommended that Cunningham serve the maximum ten years in prison, pay $1.5 million in taxes and forfeit $1.85 million in bribe money and items provided by co-conspirators. On March 5 he was sentenced to 8 years and 4 months in prison and ordered to pay $1.8 million in restitution.    On November 28, 2005 Cunningham pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit at least $2.4 million in bribes, the most ever congressional bribes, and $1 million tax evasion. Wade was indicted. Three unindicted co-conspirators were Brent Wilkes, ADCS, Inc.; Thomas Kontogiannis; and John T. Kongogiannis. Prosecutors could have asked for 20 years incarceration, but requested 10 years, payment of $1.5 million in taxes and penalties, and forfeiture of $1.85 million in bribes. Wade pled guilty February 24, awaiting sentencing. On March 3, Cunningham was sentenced to eight years and four months, the longest for any congressman, and $1.8 Million restitution.    Rep. Randy Cunningham resigned from Congress after pleading guilty to taking at least $2.4 million in bribes to help friends and contributors win federal defense contracts. The FBI is still conducting its investigation of defense contractors and others tied to Cunningham. He kept a "bribe menu" on congressional stationary indicating how much he demanded in exchange for federal contracts. A federal judge sentenced Cunningham to eight years and four months in prison. Cunningham was also ordered to pay $1.8 million in restitution.    Duke Cunningham resigned from Congress after pleading guilty to taking $2.4M in bribes from defense contractors. Cunningham pled guilty to one count of tax evasion and one count of conspiracy to commit bribery, tax evasion, wire and mail fraud. Cunningham had received cash, cars, rugs, antiques, furniture, yacht club fees, moving expenses and vacations for helping contractors win government contracts. A federal judge sentenced Cunningham to eight years and four months in prison. The government seized Cunningham's share of profits from the $2.6M sale of his home. The IRS will auction the gift items that Cunningham illegally received.   </text> <scu uid="1" label="Cunningham resigned from Congress on Nov. 28, 2005">  <contributor label="Cunningham resigned from Congress on Nov. 28, 2005">   <part label="Cunningham resigned from Congress on Nov. 28, 2005" start="61" end="111"/>  </contributor>  <contributor label="Rep. summary: The National Bureau of Production Safety Supervision and Administration aims to resolve all small coal mine problems within three years. Meanwhile accidents continue. Measures to improve safety include shorter working hours, fire control and ventilation equipment, and a national network of safety inspectors. Automatic gas monitors were installed in 22 gas-rich coal mines. China fired two provincial deputy governors, prosecuted 96 officials and fired or demoted 126 more after accident investigations. China has created a whistleblowers fund to reward citizens reporting negligence and illegal mine investors. Mine safety remains a major challenge as coal represents 67% of China's energy resource.    Government officials have announced that 4,000 small coalmines will be closed by the end of 2005.  One city in north China has imposed huge fines on coalmines for each death in accidents.  In Hunan Province cash awards are offered to those who report officials who illegally own shares in mines.  In December 2005 the government announced that it had dismissed two provincial deputy governors, prosecuted 96 officials and demoted or dismissed 126 other officials blamed for accidents killing 528 people.  Despite such measures the rate of large-scale accidents increases with accidents reported on a near-daily basis.    Accident and death rates continue to increase at China's provincial coal mines, while rates decrease at state-owned facilities. In response, officials will close 4,000 small coal mines annually for three years and further reduce the number through regrouping and mergers. Already, 2,411 mines were closed this year and 12,900 were ordered to suspend production for safety problems. Fines have been established for wrongful deaths, and rewards offered to whistleblowers. Advanced gas monitors were installed in 20-some gas-rich coal mines. Two deputy governors were dismissed, 96 officials were prosecuted, and another 126 officials were demoted or fired for safety violations.    China has set a timetable for solving the problems associated with its thousands of small coalmines. Many of these mines will be closed, an action that won't affect China's demand for coal. Thirteen large coal production bases each capable of turning out 100M tons annually have been approved. In one region, gas monitors have been installed as a safety measure in gas-rich coalmines. Hunan Province is offering cash rewards to people who report on officials who illegally own shares in coalmines. Some officials have been dismissed. By December, 12,990 mines were ordered to stop production due to safety problems. </text> <scu uid="187" label="Bur. of Prod. summary: Martha Stewart reported to a federal prison in Alderson, West Virginia on Oct. 8, 2004 to serve a five-month sentence. She is very busy. Being deluged with letters, she spends up to three hours/night at a prison typewriter. She has some duties such as cleaning toilets but is treated with respect and spends most of her time reading and making friends. She takes walks, goes to the gym and watches TV. She has one roommate and is working on innovative ways to do microwave cooking to share with inmates. Her only real complaint is the "terrible" food.    Martha Stewart reported to the Alderson Federal Prison Camp, known as Camp Cupcake, in West Virginia on October 8 to begin serving a five-month sentence. She began her sentence despite her pending appeal in order to sooner put her nightmare ordeal behind her and reclaim her good life. Stewart arrived in good spirits and adjusted well. Prison officials and fellow inmates have been nice. She keeps busy performing chores, taking walks, exercising in the gym, reading, writing, watching television news, and creating innovative microwave recipes. She's received thousands of letters from fans and has had visitors, including her daughter.    Martha Stewart, founder of a multimillion-dollar publishing and home-decorating empire, will be serving a 5-month sentence for lying to federal investigators about her suspiciously timed stock sale. In a web site letter, Stewart says she is adjusting to life behind bars. Stewart is spending time figuring out innovative way to do microwave cooking among other activities. She was touched by the outpouring of support she received from millions of people who visited her web site and urged fans to send donations to the American Cancer Society. Stewart's lawyer has filed an appeal.    Martha Stewart arrived in good spirits for her five-month term at Alderson Federal Prison Camp. She was treated with respect and thought inmates and officials were all nice. She was issued clothing but could also wear an inexpensive watch and earrings. She had one roommate in a dormitory-like building. She exercised, took walks, cleaned toilets, read, subscribed to newspapers, watched TV news, made friends, developed innovative microwave cooking ideas for inmates, and wrote. She kept in touch with supporters through her website and was touched by the many letters. She played scrabble with her daughter Alexis during visits.  </text> <scu uid="1" label="Martha Stewart was to serve a five-month sentence">  <contributor label="Martha Stewart...to serve a five-month summary: The State Legislature group concluded that States are focusing cell-phone legislation on younger drivers and school bus drivers. These laws are more likely to pass and maintain their constituents support. The cell-phone industry states that the percentage of accidents caused are very low. Judging cell-phone law results are difficult due to the lack of clear evidence in accidents except from witnesses or driver admissions. Driver education is a large part of cell-phone law enforcement. A National Highway Traffic Safety Administration survey prompted the Department of Defense to restrict driver cell-phone use on military facilities. Enforcement policies vary by military base.      In 2005, 38 states tried to pass legislation restricting cell phones while driving. Bills were passed or are still being considered in 22 states. The National Transportation Safety Board is urging states to restrict young drivers because teens account for a large share of traffic fatalities and cell phone use increases the problem. However, enforcing laws for young drivers is difficult. Both the U.S. Virgin Islands and Lackland Air Force Base have cell phone laws in place.    Every state has considered legislation on cell phones behind the wheel but only a few have banned them unless they are hands-free. Connecticut and Chicago have joined New York, New Jersey and DC in prohibiting use of hand-held phones. Many states have put limits on teens using cell phones while they drive. Enforcement of laws banning cell phone use while driving is a problem. Nearly everyone supports the laws, nearly everyone ignores them. The Defense Department approved restrictions on cell phone use by motorists but left it for the military services and individual bases to decide how to enforce it.    The US Virgin Islands now bans hand-held cell phone use while driving. Eleven states including Colorado, Delaware, Maryland and Tennessee ban cell phone use by young drivers. California prohibits phone use while driving by bus drivers but not others. Under a Pentagon directive, bans on cell phone use while driving are becoming common on military bases. In 2005, 38 states tried to pass restrictive legislation. Effectiveness is difficult to assess because drivers or witnesses must confirm cell phone use coincided with accidents. Enforcement is difficult because officers can't easily ascertain drivers' ages or if they are using hands-free phones. </text> <scu uid="26" label="States have tried to pass restrictive summary: "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince," number six in the series by British author J.K. Rowling will go on sale in July 2005. The publication date will be simultaneous in several countries. Bloomsbury Publishing's stock surged with the news. More than 5 million pre-orders have been received by booksellers worldwide. 10.8 million copies of the first printing and 635,000 audio book copies will be available in July. Four separate editions are planned for US and UK audiences. In two separate cases, theft and accidental pre-release sales, injunctions forbidding the leaking of details prior to publication were issued.    J.K. Rowling's sixth novel in the Harry Potter series will go on sale on July 16 in Britain, the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa and China. The announcement delighted readers, booksellers, and owners of Bloomsbury Publishing stock, whose shares surged 7%. Within 24 hours, the book shot to Number 1 on Amazon's bestseller list. British police arrested two men for the theft of two copies of the book six weeks before its launch. A Canadian bookstore accidentally sold up to 15 copies about a week early, and a court injunction barred anyone from leaking the plot.    Rowling's sixth Harry Potter novel was announced in December 2004, to go on sale July 16th. Bloomsbury stock surged to an all-time high. Advance orders at Amazon and Barnes & Noble each topped one million. Rowling announced one character wouldn't survive. First printing would be 10.8 million. British police recovered stolen copies from two men preparing to sell them six weeks early. Fifteen copies were sold early in Canada. Court injunctions kept anyone from leaking story details. Warehoused books were kept under 24-hour guard. Rowling invited 70 children from English-speaking nations to join her at Edinburgh Castle for the launch.    The sixth novel in J.K.Rowling's Harry Potter series, "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince," will go on sale at 12:01 a.m. on July 16. Long before its release, the book was breaking all publication records. The first U.S. printing was to be 10.8 million copies, with 635,000 copies of the audio book. Amazon.com had more than 1.2 million pre-orders world-wide and bookstores expected to sell 50,000 copies an hour for the first 24 hours. summary: Prescription drug plan Medicare Part D has been launched with a bombardment of information to seniors. The enrollment period is from November 15 to May 15 with coverage beginning January 1. There may be costly penalties for those that do not sign up by the deadline. The majority of seniors are confused and overwhelmed by all the plan choices. Making the wrong choice has the potential to cost more than they are currently paying. Seniors not computer literate must rely on phone representatives newly trained in the plan details. Many seniors are giving up in frustration and not enrolling.    Benefits from the Medicare Part D prescription drug program will not begin until January 1, 2006, but Medicare beneficiaries may sign up beginning November 15, 2005. The choice is difficult - not just whether to join, but which of a multitude of plans is best for an individual. Choice of the wrong option can endanger benefits already provided by Medicare or other programs. The problem is so baffling that Medicare has established a hotline and a website to help applicants, but users complain that the website is ponderous and the representatives on the hotline are often misinformed.    Medicare Part D enrollment for Medicare beneficiaries began November 15, 2005 though May 15, 2006 for coverage starting January 1, 2006, with a 1% penalty per month for late enrollment. The Part D Drug Discount Card expired May 15. After a $100-million information campaign, 33% of seniors felt informed; 37% thought they would benefit. Seniors choosing a Medicare Part D-approved private drug insurance plan risk loosing their other medical insurance. Employers used Part D federal subsidies to reduce retirees' overall health premiums; others dropped retiree health plans entirely. Of 40 million elderly Medicare beneficiaries, 28 million will enter Part D.    Medicare beneficiaries are eligible for Part D prescription drug coverage. Medicare patients can obtain the drug benefit, which becomes effective January 1, 2006, through two types of private plans: a prescription drug plan (PDP) or a Medicare Advantage plan (MA). If a senior purchases a Part D plan, any prior drug benefit will be voided. The government will not negotiate prices or discounts under the plan. Employers who offer drug coverage to those over 65 are required to provide comparisons of their plan and Part D. summary: Talks with North Korea reconvened following a five-week break. The U.S. and North Korea remain at a stalemate on the nuclear weapons program. A joint statement was signed with North Korea agreeing to rejoin the Treaty, to permit international inspectors, and to discontinue their nuclear weapons program. No timetable was determined. The international community promised to provide aid, security, energy assistance and work towards improving relations. The day after signing the statement North Korea reversed their decision to cease the weapons program until they receive a light-water reactor to create electricity.    The September 19, 2005 six-nations agreement included: N.K. giving up its nuclear weapons program; returning to the NPT and IAEA safeguards; The U.S. declared no nuclear arms on the Korean Peninsula and no intention to attack N.K.; S.K. reaffirmed it doesn't have and won't deploy nuclear weapons; China, Russia, S.K., the U.S. and Japan agreed give N.K. a light-water reactor; N.K. and the U.S. pledge to respect each other's sovereignty, coexist peacefully, and normalize relations; N.K. and Japan agreed to normalize ties; China, Russia, S.K., Japan and the U.S. gave N.K. energy assistance. Australia offered N.K. energy, aid and expertise.    Talks with North Korea end with the signing of a joint statement. The document states that North Korea agrees to abandon its nuclear weapons programs and return to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty in return for recognition of its right to nuclear energy. It also agrees to submit to International Atomic Energy safeguards. China, Russia, South Korea, Japan and the US give North Korea energy assistance and agree to discuss giving a light-water nuclear reactor for generating electricity. North Korea won't dismantle its nuclear program until it receives the reactor.    The six-party talks aimed at getting North Korea to abandon its nuclear programs resumed 13-19 September. Pyongyang pledged to abandon its nuclear programs, to rejoin the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, and to follow IAEA safeguards in return for a pledge of aid and security. The U.S agreed not to attack North Korea. China, Russia, South Korea, the U.S., and Japan agreed to give North Korea energy assistance including a light-water reactor. But the deal fell apart almost immediately, when Pyongyang insisted that it would not dismantle its nuclear weapons program until the reactor was built. </text> <scu uid="49" label="Talks with NK summary: The Jan.30, 2005 election produced only one seat for Christian Parties in the 275-seat Iraq National Assembly. Christians protested irregularities which prevented many from voting. Now the main concern was that minority rights be enshrined in the constitution to be written by the National Assembly. On March 16, 2005 a Christian general in the Iraqi police force was shot dead by a group affiliated with Al-Qaeda. In November in Baghdad gunmen killed four Christian women. Emigration of Iraqi Christians continues with the number since the American takeover estimated from 20,000 to 200,000.    US members of the Iraqi Christian minority living in the US voiced hope for national unity in Iraq's first free elections. Hundreds of Iraqi Christians protested voting irregularities outside of Baghdad's Green Zone. Many polling places opened late or never opened. Those that opened didn't have ballots or election material. Although not written yet, Iraqi Christians fear that the new constitution will favor Islam over Christianity. More killings of Christian Iraqis occur including a Christian general. Yet, they celebrate Christmas and some hope to flee Iraq.    Christians in Mosul protested polls not opening for "security reasons", keeping 200,000 from voting. Christians won one National Rafidain List seat in the new National Assembly and five spots on Kurdish and PM Alawi tickets. Christians demand the new constitution not be based solely on the Koran and include religious freedom. A Christian police general was assassinated in Kirkuk and four Christian women were murdered in Baghdad. Catholics celebrated a mass for Pope John Paul II. Christmas celebrations became low-key. The Roman Catholic community in Baghdad fell from 60,000 to 5,000. A bombed church was rebuilt with a high wall.     In January elections, Christians won only six seats in the new National Assembly. Outside the Green Zone Christians protested voting irregularities. The 71-member committee drafting the constitution included only one Christian, leading to fears that the document would not recognize minority religious rights. Christians gathered under police protection for a special mass for Pope John Paul II. But violence continued. A Christian police general was killed in Kirkuk. Gunmen killed four Christan women in a Baghdad Christian neighborhood. And some churches were surrounded by tall walls and guarded with rifles. For safety, Christmas midnight mass was held in daylight. </text> <scu uid="1" label="Christian parties win only one seat in 275-seat National Assembly for Christian Parties">  <contributor summary: Russia restored the reduced gas flow through Ukrainian pipelines which had sparked emergencies throughout Europe raising questions about Russia's reliability. The reduction was critically viewed as a foreign policy tool. Ukraine, accused of gas theft, responded that the withdrawal was routine. Russia was charged with acts of terror in pipeline explosions in Georgia. Croatia and Hungary are considering an Adriatic Sea pipeline to decrease reliance on Russia. The European Union imports some gas from Russia but parts of Europe are mainly Russia dependent. A proposed trans-Caspian pipeline linking gas directly to the West bypassing Russia is causing renewed conflicts.    Gazprom intends to remain the leading gas supplier to Europe and to expand its markets. However, Russia's disruption of gas supplies to Europe during freezing weather raised concerns about the company's ability to ensure steady fuel supplies. Pipelines supplying Russian gas go through Ukraine and each country blames the other for the shortage. Croatia and Hungary are weighing construction of a pipeline from the Adriatic Sea to bring Middle Eastern gas to Europe and decrease reliance on Russian gas. Russia has opposed a US-backed pipeline project that would bypass Russia and link Central Asian gas fields directly to the West.    Faced with mounting criticism, Russia restored gas withheld from Ukraine in an alleged pricing dispute but suspected to be Moscow's meddling in Ukraine's internal politics. Steady fuel supplies from Gazprom became questioned. Austria proposed a gas pipeline from Iran to Austria as part of Nabucco. Gas pipeline explosions in January 2006 were blamed on both Moscow and terrorists. Croatia and Hungary are considering a liquified petroleum gas terminal on the Adriatic coast and a pipeline to Europe to decrease reliance on Russian gas. A US-backed trans-Caspian pipeline is proposed that would bring Central Asian gas to Europe and bypass Russia.    Russia cut the flow of natural gas through the Ukrainian pipeline in early January because of a pricing dispute. The resulting European energy crisis made European governments question Russia's reliability and seek alternative sources. Austria is weighing the construction of a pipeline from Iran through Turkey and the Balkans. Croatia and Hungary are considering a pipeline to bring liquid gas from North Africa and the Middle East. The U.S.supports a proposed pipeline under the Caspian Sea to bring gas from Turkmenistan and Kazakhstan through Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Turkey. summary: On Oct. 27, 2005, a little more than three weeks after offering the nomination of Harriet Miers, President Bush announced that she had withdrawn her nomination. Many expressed sympathy for how she had been treated. Republicans, including Miers herself, blamed failure of the nomination on the Senate Judiciary Committee's demands for documents from the White House, but the committee chair denied intruding on executive privilege. Democrats blamed the failure on right-wing ideologues. Sen. Lott (R-MS) blamed it on a nomination based on cronyism. On Oct. 28 President Bush said he would quickly select another candidate.    Harriet Miers withdrew her nomination from consideration as a Supreme Court justice. Members of the Senate Judiciary Committee questioned her conservative credentials, lack of judicial experience and criticized her for not completely answering a questionnaire about her work at the White House. Others said the White House bungled the nomination from the start. Many agreed that although she is a very capable person, President Bush shouldn't have chosen someone not qualified to serve on the Supreme Court.     President Bush announced that Harriet Miers had withdrawn her nomination for the Supreme Court. The announcement was met with a blend of regret, relief and a feeling that she had been treated poorly. Miers said her withdrawal was to avoid burdening the White House over access to documents on advice she gave Bush since lawmakers had requested those documents. Some senators said that she had been the victim of bad handling and the White House had capitulated to the far right wing of the Republican Party. Right Wing partisans expressed relief and some jubilation at her withdrawal.    Harriet Miers withdrew her nomination to the Supreme Court three and a half weeks after its initial announcement. Bush declared on 27 October that his choice had withdrawn her name and that he had "reluctantly accepted" her decision. She claimed that the fight over her nomination would be a burden for the White House. She also said that she wanted to protect the independence of the executive branch, citing the battle over access to her White House legal writings. She will continue to serve as White House counsel. Bush promised to name a replacement "in a timely manner." </text> <scu uid="1" label="Harriet Miers withdrew her nomination to the Supreme Court.">  <contributor label="President Bush announced that summary: Steroid use appears rampant in Major League Baseball based on former player revelations and the BALCO steroid distribution scandal. Steroids were banned by the League in 2004 but it did not include designer or precursor steroids. The new Anabolic Steroid Control Act makes steroid precursors controlled substances. Congressional hearings on steroid use are being held. Former and current team members and League officials are being called to testify, some by subpoena. The League's testing program is weak compared to World Anti-Doping Agency standards. Lawmakers are considering stronger action if the League does not impose mandatory bans to police the League.    Major League Baseball players who have admitted to using steroids include Ken Caminiti, Mark McGwire and Jose Conseco. Players suspected of steroid use include Barry Bonds, Sammy Sosa, Jason Giambi, Rafael Palmeiro, Ivan Rodriguez and Juan Gonzalez. MLB's recently toughened penalties of fines from $10,000 to $100,000 and suspensions from 10 days to one year are far below international anti-doping standards. US lawmakers passed the Anabolic Steroid Control Act which added steroid precursors to the list of controlled substances. In their investigation of steroid use in Major League Baseball, lawmakers found the penalties for positive steroid tests inadequate.    After the death of former baseball star Ken Caminiti, an admitted steroid user, the US House of Representatives amended the Controlled Substances Act to include additional types of steroids. Major league baseball players who are accused of, or admitted, using steroids are Mark McGuire, Jose Canseco, Barry Bonds Sammy Sosa, Jason Giambi and Raphael Palmiero. Commissioner Bud Selig said that the testing program in place for two years showed a drop in positive tests for steroids. That program has been criticized as too lenient. Baseball executives and players union leaders have agreed to toughen penalties for the current season.    Major League Baseball players Ken Caminiti, Mark McGwire, and Jose Canseco admitted taking steroids. Barry Bonds, Sammy Sosa, Jason Giambi, Rafael Palmeiro, Ivan Rodriguez, and Juan Gonzalez are accused or suspected of steroid use. Caminiti claimed half the players used them. 5-7 percent of players tested positive in 2003 and 1-2 percent in 2005. Baseball Commissioner Bud Selig investigated steroid use in 1998 and urged banning over-the-counter sales. A pamphlet in English and Spanish on steroids' effects was distributed to players. Drug tests for players began in 2004. Some steroids became controlled substances. Congress held hearings on baseball steroid use. </text> <scu uid="1" label="Congress held hearings on baseball steroid use">  <contributor label="Congress held hearings on baseball steroid use"> summary: The distress of Hurricane Katrina evacuees forced to choose between rescue and pets has prompted a review of disaster preparedness. Evacuees expected to return within days to rescue their pets instead of the weeks that have passed. Humane and animal welfare organizations are mounting search and rescue efforts and providing shelter and medical treatment. They have requested federal, state and local assistance. Soldiers are being re-deployed for animal rescue. More than 4,000 animals have been rescued with some being sheltered in other states. Animals are micro-chipped and photographed to assist in reunification. Monetary and animal supplies donations are continuing.    Hundreds of animal welfare workers and volunteers from the gulf coast and across the nation are working to rescue pets stranded by Hurricane Katrina. The Humane Society, SPCA and other organizations have joined the effort. The ASPCA has received donations of over $5.25 million, and shipments of food and supplies. Nearly 4,000 animals have been rescued, and 300-400 have been reunited with their owners. Hundreds of animals arrive daily at the Lamar-Dixon Center in Gonzales, LA where about 2,000 are housed. The animals are photographed, micro chipped and documented before being shipped to other shelters. Pictures are posted on Petfinder.com.    Hurricane Katrina evacuees were forced to abandon possibly 50,000 dogs, cats, birds and other pets. Volunteers with the Humane Society, the ASPCA, other groups, and soldiers searched for pets trapped in houses and left food for animals roaming streets. Rescued pets were taken to Gonzales, LA and Hattiesburg, MS. 4,000 pets had been rescued by 9/13/05 and a small fraction reunited with owners. To ease overcrowding some dogs were relocated to other states after being photographed, microchipped and documented. Pet photographs were posted on the website petfinder.com. Federal, state and local assistance was requested. The ASPCA received over $5.25 million.    Hurricane Katrina has left thousands of animals stranded in New Orleans. Many pet owners were forced to abandon their animals in the evacuation of the city, although some owners stayed, refusing to leave without their pets. The Humane Scociety and the SPCA are doing their best to rescue the animals, which include dogs, cats, horses, reptiles, and even a sea lion and a tarantula. Web sites are being used to try to reunite pets and their owners. And many animals are being photographed, microchipped, and documented and then shipped to shelters and foster homes in other states. </text> <scu uid="263" label="thousands of animals stranded in New summary: Investigations of lobbyist Jack Abramoff and his partner Michael Scanlon by the Senate Indian Affairs Committee in 2004 resulted in other investigations. The pair's lobbying for Indian tribes and Pacific islanders was shown to have benefitted the lobbyists and political associates while bilking the clients of millions of dollars. The House majority leader and a congressman were implicated. On Nov. 18, 2005 Michael Scanlon was charged with fraud and scheduled to go to court on a conspiracy count contained in a criminal information, typically a prelude to pleading guilty and giving full cooperation with government investigators.    Republican lobbyist Jack Abramoff and his associate Michael Scanlon are at the center of a growing corruption scandal. The investigation began with allegations of fraud in dealings with a number of American Indian tribes, but widened to include golf junkets and dealings in the Northern Marianas. The scandal has focused attention on a number of members of Congress and their associates, including House Majority Leader Tom DeLay of Texas and Rep. Robert Ney of Ohio. Abramoff has been arrested on fraud charges stemming from a Florida deal. Scanlon is expected to plead guilty to charges and cooperate with government investigators.    The Senate Indian Affairs Committee charged Jack Abramoff, a GOP lobbyist and fund-raiser, with running a crude extortion racket that has bilked tribes out of millions of dollars. House Majority Leader Tom DeLay, additional congressmen and House aides are under an ethics investigation resulting from their connections with Abramoff. His activities in the Northern Marianas are also being investigated. Abramoff has been indicated in federal court on six counts of fraud and conspiracy and his partner, Michael Scanlon, was charged with defrauding Indian tribes of millions of dollars.     Republican lobbyist Jack Abramoff is being investigated in connection with manipulating elections and extorting lobbying fees of $66 million from six Indian tribes related to protecting gaming franchises, and $9 million from the Northern Mariana Islands related to the textile industry. Investigations also involve Abramoff's purchase of a gambling cruise ship company and arranging unreported golf junkets to Scotland. Abramoff invoked the Fifth Amendment before a Senate hearing. Also implicated are Republican Majority Leader Tom DeLay, his former aide Michael Scanlon, Ralph Reed, Representative Robert W. Ney, and David Safavian. Safavian was indicted in connection with a golf trip.  </text> <scu uid="1" label="Jack Abramoff is a  GOP lobbyist">  <contributor label="Jack Abramoff, a GOP lobbyist">   <part label="Jack Abramoff, summary: On March 24, 2005 mass protests outside the presidential compound in Bishkek turned violent. Demonstrators broke into the building and beat several officials severely. Akayev fled the country for Russia and soon announced in Moscow that he would resign if the Kyrgyzstan government would guarantee his safety. On April 3 a Kyrgyzstan parliamentary delegation arrived in Moscow and after 3 hours of talks Akayev signed a resignation document. He also taped an 18-minute farewell address to be played in Bishkek while he remained in Moscow. New presidential elections are scheduled for June 26.    On March 24, 2005 protestors stormed the main Kyrgystan government building and Akayev fled to Russia. The elected pro-Akayev parliament nonetheless elected an Akayev opponent as Speaker and called for new presidential elections on June 26. On April 3, Akayev signed his resignation in Moscow, which was notarized in lieu of a constitutional requirement that he present his resignation in person to parliament. Because his safety still could not be guaranteed, due to continued calls for his impeachment, his recorded resignation was to be heard and accepted by a special session of parliament on April 6 and broadcast live.    Opposition against Akayev strengthened with international criticism for election abuses, his government's crackdown on opposition groups and independent media, and his failure to bring those responsible for killing six peaceful demonstrators in 2002 to justice. Poverty and widespread corruption contributed to public anger. Akayev fled to Russia after opposition supporters stormed the main government building and mobs looted parts of Bishkek. He resigned as president in Moscow, with impeachment the alternative. In his address to the nation, Akayev apologized to people who bore him grudges, hoped the presidential election would be democratic, and said he wouldn't fight the new government.    Massive uprisings continued in Kyrgyzstan, fueled by anger over the rigged parliamentary elections. When protesters finally stormed the presidential compound on 30 March, President Akayev fled to Moscow. Two nights of looting and gunfire followed in Bishkek. A delegation headed by the new speaker of Parliament went to Moscow to negotiate with Akayev. Akayev signed his formal resignation at the Kyrgyz Embassy in Moscow on 4 April. His recorded statement was to be shown to Parliament and then broadcast on national television. Presidential elections are now scheduled for 26 June. </text> <scu uid="7" label="Akayev fled the country for Russia.">  <contributor label="Akayev fled the country for Russia">   <part label="Akayev summary: U.S. District Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow's mother and husband were shot at her home in an apparent retaliation for her contempt order against Matthew Hale, a previous defendant in a civil copyright lawsuit with white supremacist elements. Hale is currently in federal prison awaiting sentencing for previously soliciting the murder of Lefkow. Federal agents and police are investigating Hale's colleagues and looking for two men seen near Lefkow's home at the time of the murders. Evidence recovered at the scene include: shell casings, a fingerprint, footprint, and cigarette butts. Hale denies any involvement in the murders.     Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow's husband and mother were murdered in their home on February 28. They died of multiple gunshot wounds between 10:30 a.m. and 5:30 p.m. Evidence being analyzed includes broken window glass with a fingerprint, a bloody footprint, .22-caliber shell casings, a bloody mop and cigarette butts. Investigators released composite sketches of two men seen near the home on the day of the killings. A $50,000 reward is being offered for leads in the case. The prime suspect is domestic extremist Matthew Hale, convicted last year of soliciting her murder. He and his supporters deny any involvement.    Once white supremacist Matthew Hale was convicted and in jail for plotting to kill Judge Joan Lefkow, her security detail was dropped. Killers entered her house, had her husband and mother lie on the basement floor, and shot each to death. Police and FBI investigated widely but focused on Hale and his violent supporters. Evidence included a window shard with a fingerprint, a bloody mop and shoeprint, cigarette butts, and 22-caliber shell casings. Witness sightings of two white men waiting in a red Ford Escort produced composite sketches. Investigators seized communication and computer records and offered a $50,000 reward.    The husband and mother of U.S. District Judge Joan Lefkow were killed in the basement of her Chicago home on 28 February. Investigators found a bloody footprint and fingerprints butts at the scene. There are no suspects. Investigators have questioned relatives, friends, and supporters of Matthew Hale, the leader of a large white supremacist group, who was convicted last year of obstruction of justice and of ordering Lefkow's killing. They also want to question two men seen in a car illegally parked near the home that afternoon. summary: Pope John Paul II, 84, died in Rome on April 2, 2005 from Parkinson's disease. Sunday his body lay in state at the Vatican's Apostolic Palace. St. Peter's Basilica was closed to the public to prepare for the funeral and interment on Friday. Major security measures including a no-fly zone and marksmen are being undertaken to protect the 200 state leaders attending. Condolences and mourners from around the world are arriving in Rome. A tent city has been erected as a camp for mourners. Millions more are mourning worldwide. The College of Cardinals is beginning preparations to select a successor.    Following Pope John Paul II's death on April 2, mourners gathered worldwide. Chinese Catholic Bishops sent condolences to the Vatican. Philippine Catholics express deep grief as church bells tolled. Over 500,000 people signed an online condolence book. On April 3, the late Pope's body lay in state in the Vatican's Apostolic Palace. Hundreds of thousands of pilgrims arrived from Europe and around the world to pay their respects. Some 800,000 gathered in Krakow, Poland for a memorial mass. Hundreds of dignitaries, leaders and heads of state from around the world headed to Rome for the funeral.    Pope Paul II died after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. The Pope's body was displayed at the Vatican's Apostolic Palace and on Vatican television and will be interred in the crypt of Saint Peter's Basilica. A vast security operation went into effect as dignitaries and over a million pilgrims from around the world arrived paying their last respects. Near Krakow, Poland, 800,000 people gathered for a mass in memory of the Polish-born pope. More than half a million people have "signed" a condolence book in cyberspace.    Pope John Paul II died on Saturday night, 2 April, after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. He had had acute breathing problems for two months and had suffered a heart attack two days before his death. His body was displayed at the Vatican's Apostolic Palace on Sunday. The funeral is to be held on Friday. Two hundred world leaders are expected to attend, creating an enormous security problem. Meanwhile more than a million pilgrims have been gathering to pay their respects. His remains are to be interred in the crypt of St. Peter's Basilica. </text> <scu uid="13" label="Condolences and mourners came to Rome from around the world.">  <contributor label="Condolences and summary: Herceptin reduced HER2-positive gene-associated breast cancer recurrences 52 percent. Avastin proved effective against breast cancer. Low-grade ductal carcinoma in situ becomes invasive cancer in 40 percent of patients over 40 years. Combined chemotherapy and hormone therapy cut death in half within 15 years from recurring breast cancer. Consuming 33.3 fat grams daily reduces breast cancer recurrence 30% over five years. Exercise increases breast cancer survival 50%. Low melatonin levels in night-time workers increased breast cancer. Benign "proliferative" lesions correlate with later breast cancer. At 65 and older, early smaller localized tumors accounted for 96% of survival improvement; 38% under 50.    The drug Herceptin will soon be added to chemotherapy as a standard part of post surgical treatment for some breast cancer patients. Scientists reported that breast cancer patients who follow diets low in fat might reduce the chance that their tumors will return. A study showed that walking for three to five hours per week reduced the risk of death by 50 percent. Another study examining the role of childhood diet plays in breast cancer found an association between eating French fries regularly during the preschool years and developing breast cancer as an adult.    Risk of dying from breast cancer fell because drugs prevent recurrence and earlier-detected tumors are smaller. Herceptin halves risk of recurrence in women with tumors high in protein HER2. A low-fat diet and exercise may reduce chances of recurrence. Only removing the lymph node nearest a cancer is less invasive and accurately detects whether cancer has spread. Ductal carcinoma in situ has various grades, can be mistaken as benign, and can take 40 years to develop. Night shift workers, women with benign breast lesions, and girls who frequently ate French fries as preschoolers have a higher risk of breast cancer.     Breast cancer survival rates have improved because of better screening, leading to detection of smaller tumors when the cancer is still localized. There are two new drugs for breast cancer - herceptin and avastin. Scientists see a link between benign breast cancer lesions and later cancer. Studies have shown that both low-fat diets and exercise can increase survival rates for  breast cancer patients. But eating french fries in childhood can lead to cancer in adulthood. Night workers seem to have a higher incidence of breast cancer, indicating that there may be a relationship between tumor developent and exposure to light. </text> <scu uid="1" label="Herceptin summary: Rove remains under investigation. News organizations are requesting that the court refuse Fitzgerald's motion to keep pretrial evidence confidential. Plame is leaving the CIA. Senator Charles Schumer requested that President Bush reveal who illegally leaked Plame's identity. Libby's trial has been set to begin in January. Libby's lawyers seek dismissal of charges against him saying that Fitzgerald did not have the legal authority to indict Libby. By court order, edited government documents related to intelligence briefings will be provided to Libby for his defense. Fitzgerald opposed the request to dismiss the case saying he had the legal authority to indict.    After Libby's indictment, reporter Bob Woodward told Special Prosecutor Patrick Fitzgerald that about one month before Valerie Plame's identity was exposed, he had learned it from another Bush administration official (not Libby). Karl Rove revealed Plame's identify to Time magazine reporter Matt Cooper days before Libby revealed it to columnist Robert Novak. Portions of the Plame identity leak investigation's grand jury testimony were unsealed. Libby had told the grand jury that Vice President Cheney had authorized him to leak classified information. Fitzgerald disputed Libby's motion to a federal judge to dismiss his indictment, claiming the Prosecutor was appointed unconstitutionally.     Washington Post editor Bob Woodward acknowledged that a senior WH official, other than Scooter Libby, had told him Plame was a CIA operative before it was reported by Novak. Plame resigned from the CIA since her outing diminished her career possibilities. Karl Rove remains under investigation; he disclosed that he had told a Time magazine reporter of Plame's CIA status. Libby's attorneys continue to argue for dismissal of the case against him. It was reported that Libby will argue that Chaney authorized him to leak classified information to bolster the case for war against Iraq.    Libby's lawyers have asked a federal judge to dismiss the indictment, claiming that the prosecutor lacked the legal authority to indict Libby. The Special Counsel disputes that claim. Libby's trial has been set for January 2007. He is expected to testify that he was too involved with national security issues to recall minor events such as conversations with reporters. A federal judge has ordered the government to provide Libby with redacted versions of various documents and other information he requested. Meanwhile the special prosecutor is back at work before another grand jury with Rove still under investigation. </text> <scu uid="1" label="Rove remains under investigation">  <contributor label="Rove summary: Other power grid vulnerabilities include accidental line cuts during maintenance, equipment malfunction or failure, old grid infrastructure and poor grid design causing power loss over wider areas. Improvements in grid architectures will increase network resilience. Deregulation resulted in lower margins for reserve power capacity and transmission capacity, as well as loss of experienced personnel. As companies specialized more in generation or transmission, supervisory data became proprietary and unavailable to regional grid managers. An August 2005 federal law will create a process for mandating reliability rules. Energy conservation and smart appliances that cut back during power grid stresses can avert blackouts.    The blackout in August 2003 that struck the northeastern U.S. and parts of Canada was primarily caused by the deregulation of the utility companies. Experts said that changes in the industry had several adverse effects, including loss of experienced personnel and lawyers and MBAs now heading these competitive companies rather than engineers. Power plant capacity and its state of repair are proprietary now and not available to system operators who manage regional power grids. The energy law provides for mandatory reliability rules, but no power to enforce rules.    The factor widely considered behind the blackout of 2003 is the deregulation of the electric system. Under a regulated system, utilities could add transmission lines to increase reliability and their costs would be reimbursed through the regulatory process. Market participants prefer lower margins to drive up prices. A new energy bill now provides a mechanism for creating mandatory reliability rules. Some firms have identified advances in technology: cheap, powerful chips, more capable software and broadband communications that will impact on the energy business. Power saving devices and developing alternate power sources can contribute to the reliability of the power system.    California imposed rolling power cuts in 2001 to deal with strains on the grid. In 2005 Los Angeles suffered three significant electrical failures, due to mistakes by workers or automatic systems. In 2005 the US and Canada discussed deregulation of the electric system, widely considered to be a cause of the 2003 blackout. Utilities now have little incentive to invest in transmission lines, keep reserve power to minimize shortages, or share information on power plant operating status. Plants operate closer to reliability limits more often. MBAs and lawyers head power companies rather than engineers. Energy company ownership continues to consolidate. </text> <scu uid="1" label="Deregulation of the electric system caused the 2003 blackout.">  <contributor label="The factor widely considered behind summary: The Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO) and the French National Space Center have signed an agreement to initiate a satellite project which will gather atmospheric data. India will build the satellite and France the scientific instruments. ISRO is also considering scientific experiments from the US, UK, Sweden, Bulgaria and Germany for an unmanned lunar mission. India hopes to launch a manned mission within seven years. ISRO is assisting the Jharkhand Space Application Center launch a telemedicine satellite system to connect doctors with rural communities. Afghanistan is requesting to piggyback on the telemedicine system to assist their citizens.    The space agencies of India and France have signed an agreement to cooperate in launching a satellite that will help make climate predictions more accurate. The Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO) has short-listed experiments from the US, UK, Sweden. Bulgaria and Germany for a slot on its unmanned moon mission, Chandrayaan-1. The European Space Agency and NASA will have x-ray and laser equipment on the satellite. The ISRO will provide satellite connectivity to the Jharkhand Space Application Center for a telemedicine system to connect villagers with doctors at renowned hospitals. This network will also function in Afghanistan.    The Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO) and France will cooperate on a satellite to track tropical atmospheric conditions. ISRO has short-listed experiments from five nations (US, UK, Sweden, Bulgaria, Germany) for a slot on India's unmanned moon mission, Chandrayaan-1, which is to map the lunar surface. India can send a man into space within seven years. Its first astronaut flew on the Soviet Salyut 7 in 1984. Another died in the Columbia shuttle disaster. India plans a telemedicine system to connect hospitals and patients via satellite. India plans flight-testing of its cryogenic rocket. It sought black-market electrical components for rockets.    India's space program is developing on several fronts. India is planning an unmanned moon mission to map the moon's surface and produce a chemical map of the moon. Experiments from five countries (the U.S. and four European nations) are short-listed for this satellite. It has an agreement with France to launch a satelite perhaps in 2008 to make climate predictions more accurate. It will set up a telemedicine system, linking doctors at the best hospitals with patients across India. Afghanistan has asked India for help setting up a similar program in Afghanistan using Indian satellites. </text> <scu uid="1" label="The Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO) and France will
