summary: The 7 year legal battles between the husband and parents of Florida resident Terri Schiavo over whether to extend her life artificially continue with day to day countermanding legal rulings including Florida's Supreme Court. Florida's Governor, Jeb Bush, intervened for the parents. The U.S. Supreme Court has refused involvement. State rulings for the husband ordered the immediate removal of Shiavo's feeding tube. The U.S. Congress met in emergency sessions on behalf of the parents to write legislation allowing a federal court to hear the case.      Terri Schiavo's husband and legal guardian Michael Schiavo is involved in a seven-year court battle with her parents. Mr. Schiavo has fought for legal permission to remove her feeding tube, which has kept her alive for 15 years. Some doctors testified that Terri Schiavo is in a persistent vegetative state after a sudden heart attack, with no hope for recovery. Her parents insist that she be kept alive. She had no living will or written instructions. The legal battle in Florida is complex. A judge instructed that the tube be removed on March 18, 2005.    Michael Schiavo's legal battle to have his long-comatose wife Terri's feeding tube removed against her parents' wishes began in 1993. Courts ordered it removed in 2000 and 2003. Six days after a 2003 removal it was reinserted after Governor Jeb Bush pushed "Terri's law" through the Florida Legislature. Florida's Supreme Court struck this down as unconstitutional. The US Supreme Court declined to get involved. Florida Judge George Greer ordered the tube be disconnected on 3/18/05, rebuffing US congressional intervention efforts as having no jurisdiction. Congress then passed narrow legislation allowing Terri's parents to appeal to federal courts for tube reinsertion.    The seven-year legal battle continues over the fate of Terri Schiavo, who has been in a vegetative state for over 15 years. Doctors say that there is no hope of recovery. Her parents want to keep her alive; her husband who is her legal guardian says that she would not want to be kept alive artificially. The case is complicated and has involved state courts at several levels, both state and federal legislatures, and the governor of Florida as well as the U.S. President. As of 19 March the feeding tube had been removed by court order. </text> <scu uid="18" label="Terri Schiavo has heart attack ">  <contributor label="Terri Schiavo...sudden heart attack">   <part summary: During the morning rush hour on July 7, terrorists exploded bombs on three London subway trains and a double-decker bus, killing at least 52 and injuring 700. A group called Secret al-Qaida Jihad Organization in Europe claimed responsibility. The attacks were timed to coincide with the G-8 summit meeting at Gleneagles, Scotland. Forensic evidence indicates that each bomb contained less than 10 pounds of possibly military-grade high explosives, and all were made by a single bomb maker. There is not yet evidence as to whether suicide bombers were involved. Police are close to identifying someone responsible for the bus attack.    Four coordinated bombings struck central London on July 7, three in subway cars and one on a bus. The blasts killed 52 persons and sent 350 to hospitals where 22 remain critical. An additional 350 were treated for light injuries. Hot, dusty conditions in subway tunnels hampered rescue operations. PM Tony Blair returned to London from the Group of Eight meeting in Scotland after the bombings. Police said each bomb contained less than ten pounds of military-grade explosives and did not rule out suicide bombers as responsible. A group called Secret al-Qaida Jihad Organization in Europe claimed responsibility.    Four coordinated bombs exploded in central London during morning rush hour on July 7th, coinciding with the G8 summit in Scotland. About 700 were injured and 52 killed. Three bombs were on subway trains and one on a bus. Each was small enough to fit in a rucksack. The Secret al-Qaida Jihad Organization in Europe claimed responsibility, to avenge British involvement in wars in Afghanistan and Iraq. No evidence arose of suicide bombers. Investigators viewed video by cameras on streets and subway platforms around London. Londoners took the terrorist attacks in stride, used to IRA bombs and the WWII blitz.    Four coordinated terrorist attacks occurred in London during the morning rush hour on Thursday 7 July. Bombs exploded on three subway trains and one double-decker bus. The bombs all contained similar components: military-grade explosives under 10 pounds, small enough to fit into a backpack. The explosions killed at least 52 people and injured more than 700. Investigations at the tunnel site were slow, hampered by very high heat, asbestos dust, and twisted metal. Investigators do not know how many suspects they are looking for, but reported progress toward identifying one of the bombers. </text> <scu uid="7" label="Double-decker bus bombed">  <contributor summary: In addition to the current high death toll of 1,121 victims, the severe economic impacts are being assessed. Petroleum and chemicals produced in the Gulf region were sharply reduced as was oil and natural gas extraction. The 0.1% rise was extremely below economic forecasts. Farming losses are expected to be $900 million. Part of the economic impact of Katrina is the unemployment rate in Louisiana which has risen to 11.5%. The U.S. House of Representatives unanimously passed a $6.1 billion tax assistance package for people and businesses displaced due to Katrina and sent it to the U.S. Senate for consideration.    By September 27, 2005 US Katrina deaths reached 1,121. Rescuers searched for victims as successor Hurricane Rita struck. By September 14 Brit Insurance forecast $US 50 billion global insurance losses. Gulf of Mexico oil and natural gas extraction dropped sharply. Refineries and chemical plants faltered. US Agriculture lost $US 900 million. In September Louisiana unemployment was 11.5%, from August's 5.7%. Turkey gave $US 1.5 million to the US Red Cross for Katrina relief and $US 1 million in humanitarian supplies. Bosnia's Red Cross gave money. On September 21, the US House passed $US 6.1 billion in Katrina recovery tax breaks.    The death toll from Hurricane Katrina surpassed 1,100. Turkey has allocated 2.5 million dollars for victims and the Bosnian Red Cross announced that is has started raising money for victims, as well. The US House of Representatives approved tax breaks for victims. The hurricane caused job losses in Louisiana sending its unemployment rate soaring to 11.5 percent. Agricultural losses are expected to reach an estimated 900 million dollars and US industrial output has been depressed by Katrina with severe cut backs in production of petroleum and chemicals.     As of 29 September, Katrina's death toll had reached 1121 including 885 in Louisiana and 200 in Mississippi. The economic impact was massive. The global insurance industry was predicting costs of $40-$50 billion. Agricultural losses were estimated at $900 million. Louisiana's unemployment rate soared to 11.5%. And U.S. industrial output rose only slightly because of cuts in the production of petroleum and chemicals in the Gulf region. 118 countries sent aid, including $2.5 million from Turkey. The U.S. Congress was expected to approve tax breaks of $6.1 billion for people and businesses. </text> <scu uid="1" label="Katrina's current death toll is 1,121 victims">  <contributor label="In summary: Police arrested Dennis Rader on Feb. 25, 2005 and identified him as the serial killer BTK accused of 10 killings 1974-91. BTK had taunted police with letters to them and the media, but efforts to find him failed and in 1979 the letters ceased. They resumed in March 2004 and the investigation of the BTK case reopened. Forensic experts studied DNA swabs that Kansas Governor Sibelius says linked Rader (BTK) to his victims. Little else has been revealed as to how the perpetrator of these crimes was identified and tracked down.    After two false arrests, suspected Wichita, Kansas "BTK serial killer", Dennis Rader, was arrested February 25, 2005. He was held for 10 first-degree murders, from 1974 to 1991, but won't get Kansas's death penalty instituted in 1994. Local and county police, the Kansas Bureau of Investigation, and the FBI worked 31 years on 5,000 tips and evidence provided by BTK: eight letters to police and media, a victim's necklace BTK gave to his girl friend, a victim's driver's license, BTK's recorded voice and crime scene semen, thousands of DNA swabs, BTK's DNA linking to Rader, and facts matching Rader's biography.    Wichita police arrested the BTK strangler during a traffic stop on February 25. Dennis Rader, serial killer of at least 10, sent numerous taunting messages and clues in the 1970's before going silent in 1979. In March 2004, he mailed evidence of a previously unattributed 1986 murder to the Wichita Eagle. More letters, clues and evidence followed. Thousands of tips poured in and police received help from forensics experts. Police long believed BTK graduated from Wichita State University, as Rader had. DNA evidence helped solve the case. Police learned of the last two BTK victims upon his arrest.    Wichita police announced the identification and arrest of serial killer BTK (Bind, Torture, Kill). He is Dennis Rader, a 59-year old church leader and government inspector who police believe murdered ten people between 1974 and 1991 and taunted authorities for their inability to catch him. Police received more than 5,000 tips when BTK resurfaced in 2004 after two decades of silence. The Kansas Bureau of Investigation conducted hundreds of DNA swabs in connection with the investigation. Law enforcement officials revealed nothing about the evidence they have against Rader. According to Governor Sebelius DNA evidence linked him to crime scenes. </text> <scu uid="2" label="Wichita police announced the identification of serial killer BTK (Bind, Torture, Kill)"> summary: Turkey was heavily criticized by international human rights groups over Orhan Pamuk's trial. Turkish intellectuals and EU officials demanded that Turkey change the laws that limit freedom of expression. To avoid an EU confrontation, Turkey's justice minister sent Pamuk's case back to the local Istanbul court, which then dropped the charges on a technicality. The EU welcomed the ruling, which came just days before it was to begin a review of Turkey's justice system. Turkey categorically denies Armenian accusations that up to 1.5 million died in a genocide orchestrated by the Ottoman Empire between 1915 and 1917.      A group of 169 Turkish intellectuals asked the government to scrap laws that limit freedom of expression and interfere with Turkey's democratic process. Istanbul's court dropped charges against Pamuk stating that it wasn't legally competent to judge this case. The court was chided for framing the dismissal in bureaucratic terms rather than addressing freedom of expression. About 70 intellectuals have been charged as well, but they don't have the same high profile as Pamuk. The EU pressed Turkey to address legal loopholes limiting freedom of speech in other cases.    Turkey's Justice Ministry declined to rule on whether Pamuk should be tried, citing recent penal code amendments. It sent the case back to the Istanbul court, which dropped the charges against Pamuk. The case divided Turkey and embarrassed its liberals. Pamuk's remarks also highlighted another painful episode in Turkish history, the 30,000 Kurdish deaths in recent guerrilla fighting in Turkey's Kurdish southeast. Turkish intellectuals, the EU, and most of the West called on Turkey's government to scrap laws limiting freedom of expression. Potential EU partners wanted to know that Turkish laws were the same as laws elsewhere in the EU.    The case against Orhan Pamuk ended on 23 January. The Justice Ministry had refused to issue an approval of the prosecution and told the Istanbul court that it should determine whether to proceed. The Istanbul court dropped the charges. Pamuk's lawyer criticized the decision, saying that it was framed in bureaucratic terms and avoided the issue of freedom of expression. Turkish nationalists were outraged. The EU Enlargement Commissioner said that Pamuk was not the only one facing such charges, he was "just the most high-profile case." PEN says that some 70 Turkish intellectuals have been charged with similar offenses. </text> <scu uid="6" label="The Istanbul court dropped the charges against Pamuk.">  <contributor label="the local summary: W. Mark Felt, former Deputy Director of the FBI during the Nixon Administration has ended speculation and admitted to being the mysterious Deep Throat. Felt made his revelation via his lawyer in a Vanity Fair article. The Washington Post was completely blindsided after keeping Felt's secret for 30 years. Reactions to Felt's admission varied from being declared a hero to being called a criminal. Many felt relief at no longer being suspects. Former Nixon aides decried Felt as disloyal and unethical. Bob Woodward is publishing his book on Deep Throat now instead of upon Felt's death as previously planned.    A report in Vanity Fair identifying 1972-73 Watergate leaker "Deep Throat" as the FBI Deputy Director W. Mark Felt, was verified by Felt's grandson on May 31, 2005. Felt is now 91 and in ill health. Editor Bradlee and reporters Woodward and Bernstein of the Washington Post who had kept the secret for over 33 years quickly confirmed the identification. After years of speculation individuals expressed dismay, condemnation, praise and "I told you so!" On June 2 it was announced that Bob Woodward's book on "Deep Throat" would be published in July.    Retired FBI official Mark Felt revealed himself to be the Watergate informant Deep Throat in a Vanity Fair article, ending 33 years of speculation. The revelation surprised everyone, particularly reporters Woodward and Bernstein, who vowed to keep his secret until after his death. Political celebrities, pundits, and minor Watergate figures now claim to have known all along. Felt is being hailed as a hero, denounced as a traitor and accused of partisan politics. A number of other Deep Throat suspects are relieved to be exonerated. Newspapers claim it is an example of how anonymous sources can keep government in check.    Retired FBI official Mark Felt revealed in a Vanity Fair magazine article that he was the source known as Deep Throat, famous during the Watergate scandal. Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein had pledged to keep Deep Throat's identity a secret until his death. After Felt's acknowledgement the two reporters confirmed that the now enfeebled 91-year old Felt was indeed Deep Throat. Felt's announcement ended years of speculation as to Deep Throat's identity and it freed those who were suspected from having to constantly deny that role. Former Nixon associates denounced Felt but others considered him a hero. </text> <scu uid="28" label="W. Mark Felt is former Deputy Director of the FBI">  <contributor label="W. summary: After Mikhail Saakashvili replaced Eduard Shevardnadze as the Georgian President he vowed to reunite the separatist pro-Russian regions of Georgia and fight against corruption. Adzharia was reunited but not Abkhazia and South Ossetia. Conflicts in these regions include officials screening ship passengers, the threatening of boats in Georgian waters, and the suppression of press critical of Saakashvili. He has the support of the United States in efforts to bring democracy to Georgia without war. Meetings are being held with region leaders mediated by the Russian Foreign Ministry. Saakashvili seeks an agreement between Georgia and Russia to be signed by Putin.    Mikhail Saakashvili won the presidency of Georgia in Jan. 2004 vowing to regain the separatist regions of Abkhazia, South Ossetia and Adzharia. He was successful in restoring Adzharia but has made little headway in the other two. In May he sent troops into South Ossetia culminating in an indecisive temporary cease-fire agreement in August. The same month he threatened ships bound for Abkhazian ports. He offered "the wildest possible autonomy," but his bid to open talks was rejected by the Abkhazians. By Jan. 2005 he was promising official proposals to the two by the end of the month.    In January 2004, Saakashvili regained control of Adzharia. Georgia searched ships arriving in Abkhazia. Saakashvili offered "widest possible autonomy" to Abkhazia and South Ossetia. Georgian troops entered South Ossetia despite threats of Russian intervention. Georgian coast guards fired on a Turkish ship near Abkhazia. Georgia threatened withdrawal from the Commonwealth of Independent States. Georgia and South Ossetia agreed to mutual withdrawal of troops. Georgia said it would not start a war and denied stationing 700 troops on the Abkhazia border. Saakashvilli was to make official proposals to Abkhazia and South Ossetia and finalize a framework agreement on relations with Russia.      Saakashvili's priority is to reunite pro-Russian separatist regions with Georgia. He succeeded in Adzharia, but not in Abkhazia and South Ossetia. Saakashvili has sent troops to the regions during times of heightened tensions and engaged in on-again off-again negotiations with the self-proclaimed governments. He ordered Georgian authorities to screen ships arriving in Abkhazia, threatened to sink Russian tour boats, and had coast guards fire on a Turkish ship. He closed down South Ossetia's trade in smuggled Russian goods. Saakashvili is seeking better relations with Moscow to improve relations with the renegade regions, and will soon present official proposals to them. </text> <scu uid="21" label="Mikhail Saakashvili summary: On Sept. 9, 2005 the International Cycling Union (UCI) said no action would be taken against Armstrong. On Sept. 21 the IOC Athletes Commission and the Summer Olympic sports demanded suspension of the French laboratory that accused Armstrong, claiming that its tests were illegal. The charge was made in a letter to the World Anti-Doping Agency President, who replied that the laboratory did not appear to have broken any ethical rules. On Oct. 6 the UCI President called for an independent investigator to look into the Armstrong matter in case ongoing investigations by UCI and WADA reached different conclusions.    Armstrong sued SCA Promotions for breach of contract based on L'Equip's charges. ICU's Verbruggen refuted WADA's Pound's claims Verbruggen gave L'Equip information linking Armstrong to positive 1999 erythropoietin results. Verbruggen claimed Pound blocked ICU's investigation and made "transparently erroneous statements". The International Olympic Athletes Commission and Summer Olympic Sports both demanded WADA's lab be suspended for illegally violating WADA code. The IOC and the ICU each appointed independent investigators into all issues relating to the Tour's 1999 positive tests.    Lance Armstrong continues to vehemently deny doping charges. The IOC president called for an independent investigation into allegations he used EPO in 1999. He questioned the integrity and validity of the tests and demanded the laboratory be suspended. The International Cycling Union and the World Anti-Doping Agency both announced separate inquiries. UCI and WADA have been feuding over the case. UCI accused WADA of withholding information. WADA accused former UCI president Verbruggen of leaking documents to L'Equipe.    The International Cycling Union (ICU) gave Lance Armstrong major support in his fight against doping allegations. An ICU statement said no action would be taken against Armstrong over claims that his 1999 urine samples tested positive for EPO. The ICU found no wrongdoing and no reason to condemn him. The IOC Athletes Commission and the Summer Olympic sports (ASOIF) have demanded the French lab that tested Armstrong's urine be suspended. The World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) insists the lab broke a host of rules set down by the WADA Code. </text> <scu uid="46" label="International Cycling Union (UCI) investigating allegations of summary: The FARC, Colombia's largest leftist guerrilla force, commits selective murders, slaughters and other terrorist acts. In 2003, FARC commandos attacked two Bogota pubs, targeting US citizens who frequented them. FARC kidnaps hundreds of people a year for ransom and holds dozens as exchangeables, including Colombian politicians, police officers, soldiers and currently three US citizens. Colombia's government is willing to negotiate a prisoner swap with FARC to free rebel hostages, including the three Americans. The move is encouraged by the UN. So far FARC has not agreed to the government's terms. FARC has ordered its troops to kill Colombia's president.    The Columbian Navy captured a member of the rebel group, Revolutionary Armed Forces of Columbia (FARC), who was believed to be involved in slaughtering five members of the same family. US warned US citizens in Columbia of a possible spike in "terrorist activity." FARC, with about 17,000 fighters and a smaller leftist guerilla group are locked in a 40-year civil war with the government. FARC allegedly finances itself through drug trafficking and kidnappings. About 3,500 people are killed yearly. Columbia's president is ready to negotiate a prisoner swap with FARC.      The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Columbia (FARC), the largest and oldest guerilla organization in Columbia, allegedly finances itself through drug trafficking and kidnappings. FARC, which may have 20,000 combatants, is accused of committing murders and slaughters as well as terrorist acts in different part of Columbia. FARC kidnaps hundreds each year for ransom and holds dozens of "exchangeables" including politicians, police, soldiers, and three US contractors. Columbia's President Alvaro Uribe has appealed for international support in his country's war against the rebel groups. Uribe has indicated a readiness to negotiate a prisoner swap with FARC.    Colombian President Pastrana held talks with FARC and designated a safe haven until FARC hijacked an airliner and kidnapped a senator. In 2003 FARC bombed American-frequented pubs and abducted three Americans after a plane crash. In 2004 FARC killed five members of a Colombian family and bombed a peasant home, killing one. The US designated FARC a terrorist organization and aided Colombia financially in its anti-FARC war. President Uribe offered to swap 50 jailed rebels for 50 hostages. FARC-government fighting kills 3,500 yearly. A FARC bomb narrowly missed Uribe in 2002. Uribe is pursuing an aggressive military offensive against FARC.  </text> <scu uid="1" label="The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Columbia (FARC), is the largest guerilla organization in Columbia"> summary: Criticism by Russian authorities of their Navy arose quickly following the rescue. Accident notification was delayed as in the Kursk tragedy. Putin ordered an investigation. Russian rescuers damaged their underwater robotic vehicle during the rescue attempt making it inoperable. When the British rescue vehicle arrived by air there was no equipment to unload it. Russia is considering purchasing a robotic Scorpio or Panther for underwater rescue operations. Adm. Kuroyedov, head of the Russian Navy, was fired and replaced by Adm. Masorin. Masorin has been charged with improving the Navy. Operation errors by the crew were cited as causing the accident.    Following recovery of the submarine, Russian authorities praised the international rescue effort and thanked Britain, the U.S. and Japan, but questions were soon raised as to why their navy did not have the proper equipment for such an operation. Updated equipment was soon purchased. President Putin ordered an investigation of the accident. On Sept. 4 Putin fired the head of the navy. On Sept 6 the defense minister announced that the submarine accident was a result of outrageous violations of the instructions by senior officials of the Russian Pacific Fleet and that the crew had made errors.    An investigation uncovered violations of instructions and errors in operating the mini-sub that contributed to the recent accident. Prosecutors accused a naval officer of negligence for damaging Russia's own Venom rescue vehicle, thereby necessitating international assistance. Newspapers criticized the navy for waiting over a day before revealing information about the accident. There are conflicting reports about whether the sub was caught in cables or fishing nets. The Russian navy is considering buying at least one Scorpio and possibly a newer model Panther rescue vehicle. The head of the Russian navy was fired, probably in part because of the accident.    Putin ordered the Defense Minister to launch an investigation. The head of the Navy was fired. A Navy captain was accused of damaging a Russian under-water remote-controlled vehicle in rescue attempts. Five British, one Japanese, and two Americans were given state awards. The seven crew members were given awards for bravery, but later accused of violating operating procedures and causing the sub's entanglement. The Russian navy was considering buying one or two submersible rescue vessels. The rescue cost Russia an estimated $1.5 million. Britain, the U.S., and Japan did not charge Russia for their assistance. </text> <scu uid="56" label="Putin ordered an investigation">  <contributor label="Putin ordered an investigation">   <part summary: In August 2003, former Liberian President, Charles Taylor, accepted asylum in Nigeria from 17 counts of war crimes in Sierra Leone. He has been accused of violating the asylum agreement by harboring Al-Qaeda terrorists, interfering with Liberian presidential elections and an assassination attempt on the Guinea President. The U.N.-backed Special Court for Sierra Leone is pressuring the Nigerian to send Taylor home to Liberia. U.N. peacekeepers would transfer him to Sierra Leone for prosecution. Reversing an earlier statement, Liberia's new President states that Taylor should go directly to Sierra Leone from Nigeria since he has not been indicted in Liberia.    Charles Taylor fled Liberia in August 2003 accepting an invitation from Nigeria for exile. He lived in a luxury villa near the town of Calibar near the border with Cameroon. He was accused of continuing to meddle in Liberian politics, of funding and planning the assassination of the President of Guinea and of backing Sierra Leone rebels. He was also said to give support to Al-Qaeda in its efforts to destabilize West Africa. In March 2006, Nigeria offered to return Taylor to Liberia for trial, but Liberia didn't want him so he remained in his luxury villa.    After Taylor fled Liberia, he took comfortable asylum in Nigeria, agreeing not to interfere in Liberia or other countries. Nigeria would return him to Liberia, only if a newly elected Liberia government formally requested it, but not directly to an international war crimes court in Sierra Leone. From Nigeria, Taylor meddled in Liberia's elections and implicated Al-Qaida and blood diamonds in his attempted assassination of Guinea's president, so he could move to Guinea. In March 2006 the new Liberian president requested Taylor be released to Sierra Leone vice Liberia. President Bush and Obasanjo were to discuss Taylor on March 29.    Former Liberian President Charles Taylor fled to Nigeria in August 2003 and is under house arrest at a riverside villa in Calabar. Taylor regularly defies restrictions against travel, political activity or media contact. He is actively trying to destabilize West Africa, spending money he looted from Liberia. Taylor meddles in Liberian affairs, harbors members of Al-Qaeda, and ordered an assassination attempt against Guinea's President Conte. Nigerian President Obasanjo agreed to turn Taylor over to Liberia but is pressured to send him to war crimes court in Sierra Leone where Taylor is under indictment for crimes against humanity while backing rebels. </text> <scu uid="79" label="Former President Charles Taylor fled Liberia in August 2003">  <contributor label="Former Liberian President Charles Taylor fled to Nigeria in August summary: On Sept. 22, 2004 the Office of Federal Enterprise Oversight cited numerous accounting irregularities in mortgage giant Fannie Mae (Fannie) headed by Franklin Raines. It was charged that earnings were doctored to inflate executive compensation. Raines could possibly face not only loss of his position, but fines and prison for falsifying financial statements. On Dec. 15 the Securities and Exchange Commission concluded that Fannie had indeed violated accounting rules. Lawmakers called for return of millions in executive bonuses. Raines received $14 million in salary and $25 million in incentive pay 2001-2003. Raines defended Fannie's accounting.    As late as December 21, 2004, Franklin Raines was said to be still under criminal investigation by the Justice Department for alleged financial accounting manipulations at Fannie Mae. It is not clear if Raines himself was ever under criminal investigation related to criminal charges against Time Warner and AOL, which the two companies together paid over $500 million to settle in December 2004. Those charges stemmed from alleged fraudulent accounting practices dating back to when AOL was a separate company and Director Raines was a member of AOL's audit committee.    Franklin Raines, the chairman and chief executive of Fannie Mae is defending its accounting practices and disagrees with allegations that it violated rules to maximize executive bonuses. Fannie Mae will be investigated by the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and faces litigation by shareholders. Raines and other executives could not only lose their jobs, but also face fines and prison for knowingly certifying false financial statements. They can be compelled to give back incentive pay and gains from sale of stock.    Major concerns have arisen over the leadership and credibility of Fannie Mae's CEO Franklin Raines. The regulatory agency known as OFHEO conducted the Initial investigations into Fannie Mae's accounting practices and found that the company had violated accounting rules to present a picture of financial well-being and to maximize executive bonuses. Raines has had to testify before the House Financial Services Committee. The Justice Department is conducting an investigation. The SEC has opened an inquiry into company accounting practices. The U.S. attorney's office is pursuing a criminal investigation. And eight lawsuits have been filed on behalf of shareholders. </text> <scu uid="31" label="There are allegations of accounting irregularities at Fannie Mae">  <contributor label="On Sept. 22, 2004 the summary: China's National Special Program for Food Security assists Nigeria eliminate poverty through Bamboo-based development, using Nigeria's existing under utilized bamboo forests to turn out about 300 byproducts. Over 20 insects plague northwest China's arrow bamboo, a major food source for giant Pandas. The U.S. National Zoo's research advances in giant panda reproductive cycles and artificial insemination will increase endangered giant panda populations in captivity and in the wild. India is building two commercially viable, environmentally friendly, one-megawatt, "green power" bamboo gasification-based electricity plants. A wide variety of bamboo fiber rugs are available, including kiln-dried and carbonized bamboo with polyurethane coatings.    Nigeria is using bamboo to revitalize its agriculture. It has set up a database exploring its abundant bamboo resource to produce byproducts. A state in northeast India plans to set up power stations that run on bamboo to help meet the regions energy needs. A Chinese company has successfully produced fiber from maize and blended it with bamboo fiber to make environment-friendly clothes. Forestry experts in northwest China have identified more than 20 insects, which are causing arrow bamboo to wither and die causing shortages of food for pandas. Help for pandas is being arranged.    China earned as much as $3.5B in foreign exchange from the bamboo-based sector in 2003. Nigeria hopes to follow that example and effectively explore its abundant bamboo resources that can turn out about 300 byproducts. India, second to China in bamboo production, is set to pioneer environmentally friendly power stations that run on bamboo. New products from bamboo include non-slip rugs, fiber for clothing and pre-fabricated quake-shelters. Bamboo's 60-year blooming and seeding cycle and the identification of more than 20 insects that plague arrow bamboo threaten the staple of the pandas' diet.     Retailers offer bamboo-extract towels and bamboo rugs. A Chinese company introduced bamboo fiber in 2004. A bamboo-maize blend makes soft, comfortable, wrinkle-resistant clothing. Bamboo earned China $3.5 billion in 2003. Nigeria is partnering with China to develop its vast bamboo reserve. India is pioneering a power station to turn bamboo into gas then electricity and run local paper mills. Arrow bamboo, plagued by over 20 insects, is low in nutrition but giant pandas' main food. Logging and development threaten bamboo forests. Starving people in Malawi resorted to eating bamboo seeds. Bamboo shoots contaminated with botulism sickened 163 in Thailand. </text> <scu uid="36" label="Arrow bamboo is giant pandas' main food">  <contributor label="Arrow bamboo...giant pandas' main food"> summary: By April 2005 the cause of legalizing gay marriage was making remarkable headway in Europe and Canada, edging slowly ahead in sections of the U.S. and facing aggressive opposition in some other states. Spain, Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Iceland and Finland had legalized the practice. In Canada 7 of the 10 provinces and one of three territories accepted gay marriage. In the U. S. eighteen states had passed constitutional amendments prohibiting it while Massachusetts allows and three New England states, New Jersey, California and Hawaii had taken steps toward allowing it.    Spain joined Belgium and the Netherlands as the only European countries to legalize homosexual marriages. In the US, a judge threw out an amendment to the Louisiana Constitution banning gay marriage. Massachusetts legalized gay marriage in May. Arkansas, Georgia, Kentucky, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon and Utah have all passed constitutional bans on gay marriage. A US judge ruled that California state law effectively bans gay marriage as unconstitutional. Over half of Canada's 10 provinces and tree territories allow same-sex marriage.    Homosexual marriages were legalized in Spain including the right to adopt. Some European countries have passed legislation authorizing gay marriages, but not all give gay couples the right to adopt. Poland's senate approved draft bill allowing same-sex partnerships. In Canada, seven provinces authorized gay marriages. In the U.S., gay marriages are banned in 18 states. Massachusetts legalized gay marriages and Vermont's law applies to civil unions. Judges in California and New York ruled state laws banning gay marriages were unconstitutional.    The Netherlands and Belgium allow gay marriage. Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Iceland, Finland and France give gay couples the same legal rights as married heterosexual couples. Spain approved a bill to legalize homosexual marriages. Poland's upper house approved legal partnership rights. Massachusetts allows homosexual marriage. Vermont and Connecticut allow civil unions. Judges in Louisiana and California declared state bans on gay marriage unconstitutional. Eighteen states including Arkansas, Georgia, Kansas, Kentucky, Michigan, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon, and Utah ban same-sex marriage. Saskatchewan became the seventh Canadian province to allow gay marriage. The Roman Catholic Church opposes gay marriage. </text> <scu uid="37" label="In the U. summary: The Ukrainian presidential election race to replace President Kuchma is close and competitive. Viktor Yushchenko, former Prime Minister and leader of the anti-Kuchma opposition has a small lead over Viktor Yanukovich, current Prime Minister and Kuchma supporter. Yushchenko became dangerously ill during the campaign claiming an assassination attempt. No evidence of poisoning has been found by Ukrainian or U.S. investigations. Yushchenko won the first vote but Yanukovich was declared President after a disputed runoff vote. Yushchenko demanded the results be annulled. Yanukovich offered Yushchenko the prime ministry but Yushchenko refused and called for both candidates to withdraw from the race.    In Ukraine's 2004 presidential campaign, pro-western candidate Yushchenko claimed he was poisoned by supporters of pro-Russian candidate, current Prime Minister Yanukovich. International observers alleged election violations. Yanukovich moved the Kiev Liberation Day military parade to October 29, raising fears of a military crackdown or canceled elections. State media denied Yushchenko any coverage. Students and public employees were pressured to vote for Yanukovich. Yanukovich raised pensions before the elections. On October 31, Yushchenko got 39.82%, Yanukovich 39.32%. An emergency Parliament meeting without a quorum reversed Yanukovich's November 21 victory. A healthier Yushchenko proposed new elections. Yanukovich offered Yushchenko the Prime Ministry.    Ukraine's October 31 presidential elections reduced the candidates from 24 to two, pro-Moscow Viktor Yanukovich and pro-west Viktor Yushchenko. The November 21 runoff election results are being disputed. Yushchenko is claiming Yanukovich's victory is the result of an illegal electoral commission decision and is demanding they be annulled. While campaigning, Yushchenko was struck by a mysterious illness in September and spent most of the month in an Austrian hospital. He and his supporters believe he was poisoned by political rivals. Doctors are still examining blood and other samples to determine the cause. They expect him to make a full recovery.    Ukrainian presidential elections were extremely close between the two leading candidates, pro-West Yushchenko and pro-Russia Yanukovich. Runoff elections on 21 November resulted in a standoff, with Yushchenko refusing to recognize Yanukovich as President and calling for new elections, and with Yanukovich saying that he would appoint Yushchenko Prime Minister. In September Yushchenko was treated in Vienna for a mysterious illness which paralyzed and scarred part of his face. Supporters claimed that the illness, which occurred after a meeting with the former head of the KGB, was an assassination attempt. Doctors said that they did not know the cause. </text> <scu uid="1" label="Ukrainian presidential election race close and competitive">  <contributor label="Ukrainian presidential election race to summary: China sacrificed coal mine safety in its massive demand for energy. Gas explosions, flooding, fires, and cave-ins cause most accidents. The mining industry is riddled with corruption from mining officials to owners. Officials are often illegally invested in mines and ignore safety procedures for production. South Africa recently provided China with information on mining safety and technology during a conference. China is beginning enforcement of safety regulations. Over 12,000 mines have been ordered to suspend operations and 4,000 others ordered closed. This year 4,228 miners were killed in 2,337 coal mine accidents. China's mines are the most dangerous worldwide.    Chinese coalmines are said to be the most dangerous in the world.  January-September 2005 there were 2337 coal-mine accidents killing 4228 people, up 8.5 percent from the rate in 2004.  Accidents included explosions, floods and cave-ins.  The Chinese government has issued mine-safety regulations, but enforcement is ineffective.  Mines are shut down for violation of regulations, but the demand for coal is great and many mines owned by local officials quickly reopen without sanction.  In August 2005 the government ordered all officials with coalmine investments to withdraw their stakes.    China's accident-plagued coal mines cause thousands of deaths and injuries annually. 2004 saw over 6,000 mine deaths. January through August 2005, deaths rose 8.5% over the same period in 2004. Most accidents are gas explosions, but fires, floods, and cave-ins also occur. Ignored safety procedures, outdated equipment, and corrupted officials exacerbate the problem. Official responses include shutting down thousands of ill-managed and illegally-run mines, punishing errant owners, issuing new safety regulations and measures, and outlawing local officials from investing in mines. China also sought solutions at the Conference on South African Coal Mining Safety Technology and Equipment held in Beijing.    China will close 8,648 coal mines during October 2005, for renewal of safety certificates in view of the large number of mine accidents causing loss of life. During the first nine months of the year, there were 2337 accidents killing 4228 miners. Mine safety procedures have been ignored in the quest for profits, especially by those mines owned or partly-owned by local officials. A total of 4,578 officials admitted to having stakes in coal mines. China is seeking solutions from the world, especially South Africa, to improve mining safety. By November, 12,148 mines were ordered shut down for recertification. </text> <scu uid="144" label="Mine safety sacrificed for energy">  <contributor label="China sacrificed coal mine safety in its summary: Cell-phone driving laws are having limited success in passage. Federal bills died in committee. Without a national consensus, existing state and local government laws vary widely. Drivers either ignore or are unaware of existing laws. Enforcement is not uniform. Lobbyists oppose legislation and argue driver distraction by various factors is at fault not cell-phone technology. A survey of cell phone records and accidents in Australia conducted by the U.S. based Insurance Institute for Highway Safety concludes that there is little difference between hand-held and hands-free device driver distraction. The survey confirms that cell-phone use while driving increases injuries and deaths.    The District of Columbia, New York and New Jersey passed legislation that bans using hand-held cell phones while driving. More than 400,000 tickets and warnings have been issued since New York first enacted this law. New Mexico and Chicago City only allow hands-free cell phone. Texas is considering cell phone laws. An Insurance Institute of Highway Safety survey said using any cell phones while driving is dangerous. Drivers using cell phones are four times as likely to end up in a crash as drivers who didn't use a cell phone.    Forty-five countries banned hand-held phone use while driving. In the US only New York, New Jersey and the District of Columbia completely ban hand-held phone use. Some states direct hand-held bans to specific groups such as school bus drivers or those on learner's permits. Some municipalities have enacted bans but some have been overturned by states declining to take action against cell phone use. Some jurisdictions permit hands-free cell phone use. Cell phone bills in Texas and California failed to carry. Laws are often ignored and enforcement spotty. However, Washington police average 600 tickets and 250 warnings each month.    The District of Columbia, NY state, New Jersey, Connecticut and Chicago ban the use of hand-held cell phones while driving. Some states or cities ban use with learner's permits, by school bus drivers, by minors for six months after getting their licenses, or require hands-free phones. Every state has considered restrictions but bills seldom pass. Some states, including Florida, prohibit local governments from restricting cell phone use. Hands-free and hand-held cell phones are equally distracting. Laws are often ignored. Enforcement is spotty. Hand-held phone use while driving is banned in 45 countries, including Australia, Germany, France, Britain and Japan. </text> <scu uid="1" label="Certain US places ban the use of hand-held cell phones summary: On Thanksgiving Day Stewart was able to enjoy a visit from her family, a privilege normally limited to weekends. By Christmas she was calling for sentencing reform particularly for drug and first-time offenders. By mid-January Stewart had tried her hand at ceramics and crocheting. As she completed her term in March she was 20 pounds lighter, having taught yoga and foraged for greens on prison grounds as well as abhorring the food. After leaving Alderson at 12:30 a.m. on March 3, 2005, Martha Steward declared the 5-month experience as "life altering and life affirming."    Martha Stewart spent Halloween, Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's in prison. Her job there was cleaning. During her stay, she did ceramics, crocheted, taught yoga, decorated the chapel for a memorial service, became an expert on vending-machine snacks, and foraged the grounds for fresh greens for the prison salads. She was grateful for the support of her friends, family, colleagues, and fans. Stewart became a prison reform advocate through her experience. She emerged from the Alderson prison on March 4 with head held high, 20 pounds lighter and a lot wealthier, since shares in her company nearly tripled in value.    In a Christmas message posted on her personal web site, Martha Stewart called for sentencing reform. She suggested pushing for reforms in federal sentencing guidelines for nonviolent first-time offenders and particularly for drug offenders, who would be better served in rehabilitation than prison. She is scheduled to be released in early March 2004 and then must spend five months under house arrest. Her company announced that Stewart would host a daytime talk show after her sentence. Since her conviction, her company's share price has nearly tripled increasing her personal stake.    At Alderson Martha had time to think, became a more sympathetic character, and got wealthier as her company's share price tripled. Her family visited at Thanksgiving. Martha's prison job was cleaning, sweeping, vacuuming and raking leaves. Via her website Martha received 15,000 fan e-mails, and said she was safe, fit and healthy but found the loss of freedom and privacy difficult. Fellow inmates shielded her from paparazzi. She picked wild greens to augment the bad food, lost 20 pounds, learned to crochet, taught yoga, tried ceramics, decorated the chapel, ordered seeds for her garden at home, and made to-do lists. summary: A Canadian store that sold copies of the book before the launch begged for their return. An unprecedented court injunction was issued to prevent those purchasers from reading, copying, selling, or talking about the book prior to the launch. In the first 24 hours available, the book sold 6.9 copies in the US. The second printing is being delivered to US bookstores. A Braille edition will be available within 3 days of the initial launch so the sight impaired will not have to wait. The Potter books have been translated into 63 languages with more than 300 million copies sold.    Special events were planned at bookstores worldwide, including Asia, for the much-anticipated release of Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince. The author herself was to host a special celebration at Edinburgh Castle for 70 children from around the world. A US drug store accidentally sold one copy of the book ahead of the release date. The customer agreed to return the book. The book shattered publishing records in the United States. A Braille edition of the latest Harry Potter book is was released on July 19. In October, French, Portuguese and Chinese editions of the book were released.    The publisher offered signed editions and gift packs to customers of a Canadian supermarket and US drug store who accidentally bought books early. A judge ordered Canadians not to read it until release day. A Braille edition came out three days after the simultaneous worldwide launch. French, Portuguese and Chinese translations came out in October. The 70 children attending the Edinburgh Castle launch were to write articles after being granted Rowling's only press conference. The book shattered US records, selling 6.9 million copies in the first day. A second printing hit stores immediately. Pre-orders were double those for book five.    Several copies of the sixth Harry Potter book were sold accidentally before 16 October, one in a New York drug store and 14 in a Canadian grocery store. A Canadian judge ordered those purchasers not to even read the book until the official publication date. The sale of more than 6.9.million copies in the first 24 hours in the U.S. broke all records. A second printing was already on bookshelves. The Braille edition was released three days after publication. The French translation was released on 1 October; the Portuguese, on 14 October; and the Chinese, in mid-October. </text> <scu uid="24" label="The Braille edition was released three days after summary: Open season for Medicare Part D has begun. States and local communities are offering resources in addition to the federal ones to assist enrollees due to the plan's complexities. Medicare is staffing phones round the clock everyday. The Medicare website has been so inundated with traffic that it is extremely slow or jammed thus adding to the frustration and anger of enrollees seeking information independently. Due to the extensive criticism of the plan, some lawmakers are seeking a two-year delay in its implementation. Computer savvy children of seniors are just as confused and baffled over plan details as their parents.    Calls for help have increased sharply since enrollment for Medicare Part D opened. Many organizations and volunteers try to supplement the swamped Medicare lines, but all face developing backlogs and problems training personnel. The multiplicity of options, deductibles, premiums and exceptions make comparisons overwhelming if not impossible. Some lawmakers are suggesting a two-year delay in implementation of the plan. One week into open application, The New York Times declared Part D as an attempt to do something about drug costs for seniors and at the same time protect drug and insurance companies. "It's a mess. It's hopelessly confusing."    Seniors are daunted by comparing their current coverage with Part D, baffled by hundreds of complex options, and fearful of picking the wrong Part D plan with wide-ranging premiums and unpredictable coverage changes, potentially costing them several thousands of dollars more annually. Only 6% of Medicare beneficiaries visited the balky web-based Part D plan selection tool. Many drug companies will stop offering free or subsidized promotional drugs to needy seniors. Increased competition among Part D private providers lowered some premiums, but a Senate report showed Part D drug prices are 3% higher than CostCo and Drugstore.com; 60% higher than Canada.    The Plan D's intricacies and implementation have been so criticized that some lawmakers a pushing for a two-year delay. Various consumer advocacy groups will assist Medicare enrollees in understanding Plan D. A Medicare spokesman said that the agency updated the plans and prices every Monday and that an enrollee could change plans every day until the end of 2005. When the program starts on January 1st, the enrollee will be paying the rate quoted at enrollment time. Plan D got off to a rocky start with the beginning of enrollment on November 15, because of the complexity of the system. </text> <scu uid="1" label="Open season for Medicare Part D has begun"> summary: North Korea withdrew from the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and is in a standoff with six other nations. North Korea's position is that nuclear weapons are needed for their defense. The negotiations with South Korea, Japan, China, Russia, the UK and the US to persuade North Korea to cease its nuclear weapons programs are continuing without much progress. North Korea demands to be treated as a nuclear power and for disarmament talks to apply to all countries involved. South Korea has proposed that the international community aid North Korea economically and institute a rehabilitation program once the nuclear issue is resolved.    In February 2005 North Korea declared it manufactured nuclear weapons and won't rejoin six-nation talks (North Korea, South Korea, China, Russia, Japan, U.S.). In May the IAEA reported N.K. had close to six nuclear weapons. N.K. and S.K. resumed direct talks. In July N.K. returned to six-nation talks after the U.S. recognized N.K.'s sovereignty. S.K. offered N.K. food, electricity, APEC membership, a multinational rehabilitation fund, and to establish a Northeast Asian Development Bank, if N.K. abandons nuclear weapons, which the U.S. called "premature". N.K. said it would return to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, after its nuclear weapons program was resolved.     North Korea withdrew from the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty after the United States accused the country of having a nuclear weapons program based on enriched uranium. North Korea declared in February 2005 that it has already built nuclear bombs. Since 2003, the six-nation (United States, North Korea, South Korea, China, Japan and Russia) talks have aimed at persuading North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons in exchange for diplomatic and economic benefits and security guarantees.    Several rounds of six-party tallks on North Korea's nuclear program have broken down since August 2003 without an agreement. South Korea, the U.S., Japan, China, and Russia want North Korea to abandon its development of nuclear weapons. Pyongyang insists on having nuclear power for peaceful purposes, something opposed by the U.S. South Korea has promised massive aid to North Korea, including electricity, rice, and other necessities, if an agreement can be reached within the six-party framework. It has also suggested a rehabilitation program for the North, a proposal that the U.S. and Japan strongly oppose. </text> <scu uid="16" label="North Korea is in talks with six nations">  <contributor summary: Three pipeline projects underway to transport natural gas from Asia to Europe are raising political and unspecified environmental concerns. A northern pipeline delivers gas to Germany, France and England. A central one connects Turkey to Romania, Bulgaria and Austria. The southern one supplies Greece and Italy from Turkey. The pipeline to Germany circumvents the concept of a common European policy with Russia. Russia has a monopoly agreement on gas exported from Kazakhstan produced in Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. Russia's actions are viewed as applying political pressure on neighboring countries. The pipelines are expected to begin operating between 2007 and 2010.    Gazprom, the state-controlled Russian gas group and the German company BASF plan a Baltic Sea pipeline to transport Russian gas directly to Europe. The pipeline will be launched in 2010, three years from the original estimate. It will make landfall in northern Germany then continue to the Netherlands and across the English Channel. Austria and Bulgaria plan a gas pipeline from Turkey through Romania, Bulgaria and Hungary to Austria. Construction is to begin on a Turkey-Greece pipeline to transport Caspian and Central Asian natural gas to Europe. An underwater pipeline from Greece to Italy is part of the plan.    Russia's Gazprom will control the Northern European Gas Pipeline, bringing Siberian gas directly to Europe. It will bypass Poland, Ukraine and Belarus, who fear being cut off from Russian gas. Gazprom and Germany's BASF will build it. Gerhard Schroeder, criticized for profiting from a project he supported while German chancellor, will chair the board. Gazprom arranged a monopoly on gas from Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan through Kazakhstan. The Austria-Bulgaria "Nabucco" project is a gas pipeline from Turkey to Austria. A Southern Europe Gas Ring from Turkey through Greece and across the Ionian Sea to Italy is to be completed by 2006.    The Northern European Gas Pipeline, which will bring gas from Northern Siberia through Russia and under the Baltic Sea to northern Germany, then to the Netherlands and under the English Channel to Britain. Poland, the Baltic states, Belarus, and Ukraine are critical of the pipeline, because it bypasses current transit routes through those countries. The Southern Europe Gas Ring project is to transport natural gas from the Caspian Sea area and Central Asia through Turkey and Greece then under the Ionian Sea to Italy. Construction of the Turkey-Greece segment is scheduled to start in July 2005. </text> <scu uid="1" label="The Northern European Gas Pipeline (NEGP) will bring Russian gas from Siberia">  <contributor summary: President Bush's nomination of Harriet Miers for the Supreme Court caused much consternation. The White House counsel was endorsed by the Democratic Senate leader while the Republican conservative base was splintered. Moderate Republicans sided with their president while most Democrats and liberal advocacy groups stayed out of the fray. On Oct. 12, 2005 Bush tried to promote confirmation by vouching for Miers as an evangelical Christian, but conservatives said the issue was not religion but her lack of qualifications. On Oct. 21 the Senate Judiciary Committee found Miers' answers to a committee questionnaire "inadequate," "insufficient," and "insulting."    President Bush nominated his longtime lawyer and friend Harriet Miers for the U.S. Supreme Court to replace retiring Justice Sandra Day O'Conner. Miers, currently White House counsel, would join Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg as the second woman on the court. Conservatives urged Mr. Bush to withdraw her nomination saying that she lacks the qualifications having never been a judge and has little experience in constitutional law. They further state that her nomination looks like cronyism. There is also concern that her religious belief may influence her decisions as a Justice.     President Bush nominated his longtime lawyer and friend Harriet Miers for the US Supreme Court. The announcement initially drew kind words from some Democrats but skepticism from some conservatives. Some Bush critics charged cronyism in the selection. Miers has few credentials of any kind to carry her into confirmation hearings and little experience in constitutional law. The Judiciary Committee called her response to a questionnaire inadequate, insufficient and insulting. Bush stated that part of Miers life is her religion and that appeared to further inflame the controversy. Conservatives continued to deride Miers' nomination and called for its withdrawal.    President Bush has nominated White House Counsel Harriet Miers to the Supreme Court. The nomination must be confirmed by the U.S. Senate. There is increasingly strong opposition to the nomination, with outrage expressed by conservatives such as Pat Buchanan and Charles Krauthammer. The major objections are that she has few credentials or qualifications and that the nomination looks like cronyism. Bush cited religion as one criterion for her selection. She is scheduled to face the Senate Judiciary Committee in November. The committee sent her a questionaire, but found her responses "inadequate" and "insulting" and asked her to redo it. </text> <scu uid="53" label="President Bush nominated Harriet Miers for the summary: Christians constitute about three percent of Iraq's population of 25 million. In August 2004 five churches in Baghdad and Mosul were blown up and in the following two months it is estimated that 15,000 Christians left for Syria and Jordan. Many of the emigrants blamed the attacks not on Muslim Iraqis but on foreigners. By January 2005 the Christian minority was organized into political parties in preparation for the January 30th parliamentary elections. On January 15th gunmen kidnapped the Syrian Archbishop of Mosul, an act interpreted as warning Christians not to vote in the forthcoming elections.    Iraqi Christians who are increasingly targeted by insurgents are leaving Baghdad for the Kurdish north, Syria and Jordan. The move is temporary because they aren't selling their homes and property. About 15,000 of Iraqi nearly 1 million Christians have left the country since August 2004. Insurgents abducted a Syrian Catholic Archbishop apparently to frighten Iraqi Christians in upcoming elections. Former Archbishop of Canterbury launched a campaign to assure the future of Iraqi Christian community. Their rights should be enshrined in the new Iraqi constitution and financial aid given for return to their lands and homes.    Assyrian Christians in Iraq date to the pre-Islamic first century. Modern day Christians have represented three percent of Iraq's population. Muslims regularly persecuted Christians, intent on driving them out. Iraqi Christians' future looked brighter after Saddam's fall but now looks worse, even though freedom of religion was stipulated in the interim constitution. Since the war began, over 100 Christians have been killed. Militants target Christians and try to shut their worldly business and keep them from voting. Fifteen thousand Christians have left Iraq. Twelve churches were bombed. The Chaldean patriarch's home was attacked and Mosul's Archbishop Casmoussa was kidnapped.    Christians make up about three percent of Iraq's population. Since the U.S.-led war started, armed attacks have led many to leave the country, mostly for neighboring Syria and Jordan. Several churches in Baghdad and Mosul have been attacked and more than 100 Christians have been killed, with many more wounded. Those targeted have included people helping the U.S.-led forces, as well as those in occupations seen as breaking Islamic law, such as owners of liquor-stores and beauty parlors. In mid-January, just before the upcoming elections, a Catholic archbishop was kidnapped by gunmen in Mosul. </text> <scu uid="2" label="Christians constitute about three percent of Iraq's population"> summary: The second round of AU-lead peace talks in Abuja that was temporarily suspended on October 27, 2004, ended November 10 with Sudan, SLA, and JEM signing security and humanitarian protocols. A third, hopeful round of AU-lead peace talks began in Abuja on December 11, 2004, seeking a political settlement. SLA and JEM pulled out of the peace talks on December 13, which were suspended until January, even as rebels vowed never to return until Sudan stopped attacking. December 14-17 in Ndjamena, Darfur's National Movement for Reconstruction and Development signed a separate Chad-mediated peace pact with Sudan.     Peace talks on the crisis in Sudan's Darfur region restart. But rebel leaders pulled out of the talks accusing the government of repeatedly breaching a ceasefire agreement. The African Union is trying to put peace negotiations back on track. The rebels vowed never to resume the negotiation process unless the government ends its attacks and withdraws from the troubled area. Peace talks between the Sudanese government and the rebel groups have been suspended until January 2005.    The Sudanese government and the People's Liberation Movement promised to conclude two years of talks, now in Naivasha, with a peace accord. Separate talks with two Darfur rebel groups which stopped on November 24, are to resume on December 10. This third round of Peace Talks scheduled for Abuja were halted when rebel leaders pulled out. The African Union announced that the talks have been suspended until January 2005. A third rebel group signed a peace pact with the Khartoum government at talks in Chad.    The third round of AU-sponsored talks, which started in Abuja on 10 December after a one-day delay for logistical problems, were suspended on 12 December when the rebels walked out. The two sides traded accusations of ceasefire violations. The talks are expected to resume in January despite statements by the AU mediator that the talks had not been suspended but would resume the following day. A third rebel group signed a peace pact with the Khartoum governmenton 17 December at talks in Chad. </text> <scu uid="2" label="Abuja peace talks held a second round [Abuja 2]">  <contributor summary: The U.S. Senate remains deadlocked in confirmation proceedings for Justice Janice Rogers Brown for the U.S. Appeals Court in the District of Columbia. Democrats are threatening filibusters to block her confirmation because her judicial views are considered extreme. The Senate Judiciary Committee engaged in angry debates. Republicans are threatening the 'nuclear option' as a means to end any filibusters. Republicans dismissed a Democratic proposal because it did not include the removal of filibusters. Additional compromise talks ended unsuccessfully. A new proposed agreement would allow Democrats to filibuster only in extreme circumstances. A new confirmation vote date has not been determined.    On April 21, 2005 the Senate Judiciary Committee voted to revive the long dormant nomination of Janice Rogers Brown of the California Supreme Court to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia. Brown's nomination had been blocked by Democratic filibuster during President Bush's first term. Senate leaders began negotiations over various compromise proposals on handling judicial nominations with the Republican leaders threatening to rule out the filibuster. By May 17 it appeared that Brown's nomination would not reach the Senate floor for another week or perhaps not until after Memorial Day.    In April 2005, the Judiciary Committee approved and sent for U.S. Senate confirmation, the nomination of Janice Rogers Brown to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals of the District of Columbia. Democratic Senate Minority Leader Reid promised to filibuster against her. Republican Senate Majority leader Frist threatened a parliamentary maneuver to change Senate rules to permanently eliminate filibusters in judicial confirmations, including Supreme Court nominees. Six Republican Senators and six Democratic Senators considered a pact to vote to prevent judicial filibusters, except in "extreme circumstances", and defeat filibuster rule changes. The vote on Brown's confirmation was expected in late May.    The long-dormant and controversial appeals court nomination of Janice Rogers Brown will soon go before the Senate. Republicans plan to use a parliamentary maneuver called the nuclear option that would effectively outlaw filibusters. Moderate Democratic and Republican senators have been trying to work out a compromise that would enable confirmation votes to move forward without such a rule change, so far unsuccessfully. Democrats oppose her nomination, claiming she would advance extremist conservative views, particularly on issues regarding parental notification of abortions for minors. Republicans claim she is independent and hard-working, with an open mind and a lot of common sense. </text> <scu uid="4" label="[Senate] Judicary Committee revived/approved/sent/released Brown's summary: Barack Obama, a black state senator in Illinois, first came to national attention with his electrifying keynote speech to the Democratic National Convention in July 2004. He went on to win overwhelmingly in the race for U.S. Senator. He was outstanding for his inclusive rhetoric, ability to attract support of liberals and white middle-class voters, and his fund raising for his own and other Democratic candidates. While running his own campaign he stumped for other candidates in more than a dozen states. In November 2004 Barack Obama was already being touted as a future presidential candidate.    Barack Obama graduated Harvard Law School as the first black President of the Harvard Law Review. In 2004 three-term Illinois State Senator Barack Obama won the U.S. Senate seat, with support from white liberals, the white middle class and Chicago south side blacks, to become the third black U.S. Senator in 150 years. He raised a $14 million campaign fund, and gave $400,000 to other Democratic candidates. His lauded keynote speech at the 2004 Democratic Convention kindled such star power he was recruited to stump in a dozen states for presidential nominee John Kerry.    Barak Obama, who was a relatively obscure Senate hopeful just a few months ago, soundly defeated his opponent to become the third African-American US Senator in history. The charismatic Obama catapulted to prominence after giving an electrifying keynote speech at the Democratic National Convention in July. In the following weeks, he came to have such star power that he was recruited to stump for Democratic presidential nominee John Kerry and fellow congressional candidates. He draws the support of voters from all racial and economic groups. Obama is widely touted for a future leadership position in his party.    Barack Obama studied at Columbia and Harvard and led the Harvard Law Review. He became a community organizer in Harlem and Chicago, a civil rights lawyer, and three-term state senator. He won a senatorial nomination over six others in March 2004. He rose to national prominence after his keynote address at the Democratic Convention in July. Annie Leibowitz photographed him for Vanity Fair. He raised $14 million for his campaign and donated to other Democrats. In October he won a landslide victory over Alan Keyes with cross-racial support. He was touted as a future party leader or even presidential candidate. </text> <scu uid="47" label="Obama first came to national attention with his speech to the Democratic National Convention in summary: On May 3, 2005 former President Bill Clinton announced a partnership of the American Heart Association with the food and restaurant industry to increase physical activity and nutrition at schools nationwide. Other action against childhood obesity followed in August and September as the American Beverage Association agreed to limit distribution of high caloric beverages in schools and Kraft unveiled new whole grain versions of some of the most popular cookies. It was announced in Bangkok, Thailand that fresh fruits, fruit juices and fresh milk would replace sweet and fatty foods in 433 schools across the city.    Former president Clinton launched a 10-year initiative to combat childhood obesity. The initiative, a partnership with the American Heart Association, will include working with the food and restaurant industry to promote change, increasing physical activity and improved nutrition at schools nationwide. School systems are now limiting the kinds of drinks sold to children and requiring more fruits and vegetables in school meals. McDonald's has made a major marketing shift toward promoting healthier eating habits. Kraft Foods has developed whole-grain versions of two of its popular cookies. Abroad, schools in Bangkok, Thailand are banning sugary and fatty foods and drinks.    Dr. George Bray, founding president of the North American Association for the Study of Obesity, warns that high-fructose corn syrup is a strong culprit behind childhood obesity. Bray suggests that childhood obesity can be prevented by getting more sleep, decreasing sedentary activities, drinking more milk (calcium controls weight), thinking portion control and eating breakfast. An Institute of Medicine report found compelling evidence encouraging the food industry to change the nature of foods being marketed to children. Former US president Bill Clinton announced a 10-year initiative to combat childhood obesity.    Illinois is now the only state that requires daily physical activity for public school students but Texas is proposing bills to require that. Former President Clinton his partnered with the American Heart Association to promote physical activity at schools nationwide. Many schools are limiting the kinds of drinks sold to children. California has taken the lead in purging soda and unhealthy snacks from schools. McDonalds's has made a major shift in marketing that could help redefine fast food. Kraft now produces a healthier cookie made with whole grains and containing zero grams of trans fats.  </text> <scu uid="33" label="Bill Clinton launched an initiative to combat childhood obesity"> summary: On June 16, 2005 Rep. Randall "Duke" Cunningham insisted there was nothing wrong with his living on a yacht owned by the executive of MZM, Inc. for which he had helped gain government contracts or selling a San Diego home for $1,675,000 to the executive who resold it for $975,000. On July 1 federal agents raided Cunningham's San Diego residence and the MZM offices and yacht in Washington. Cunningham soon announced that he would not seek reelection and the executive stepped down. On August 13 Cunningham asked donors for permission to use their campaign contributions for legal expenses.    By July 2005 U.S. Representative Randall Cunningham was under investigation by the FBI, U.S. Attorney's Office, Defense Criminal Investigative Service, the IRS and a federal grand jury probe. He received defense contractor MZM Inc's PAC money and personal donations from MZM President, Mitchell Wade. Wade paid a supposedly inflated price for Cunningham's and Cunningham paid Wade questionably little money to live on Wade's yacht in DC. Cunningham promoted MZM defense contracts, contributed to and served on a Wade-run charity board, and spoke at an MZM company party. Cunningham requested donors' permission to transfer campaign funds to his legal defense fund.    The FBI and other federal agencies are investigating Rep. Randall "Duke" Cunningham for selling his house in November 2003 to a military contractor, Mitchell Wade, for an inflated price. Agencies are probing Wade's efforts to repay Cunningham for his support in gaining federal contracts. Cunningham was living on Wade's yacht, which has also raised questions about improper financial links. He defended his boat arrangement as proper saying that he paid fees and services in lieu of rent. Cunningham is asking his contributors, including Wade, for permission to use their campaign donations for his legal defense.    Randall "Duke" Cunningham, R-California, is a favorite of defense contractors who contribute heavily to his political campaign. The CEO of one company, MZM, Mitchell Wade, contributes to Cunningham's campaign and PAC, but  supports the congressman in other ways. When in Washington, Cunningham lives aboard Wade's yacht docked at a Potomac River yacht club and pays only docking fees. Wade purchased Cunningham's home in San Diego for over  $1.6M and a few months later sold it for a $700,000 loss suggesting that Cunningham was paid an inflated price. After that sale, Cunningham bought another home for over $2.5M. </text> <scu uid="1" label="The FBI  is investigating Rep. summary: Ice continues to melt at an alarming rate in both the Arctic and Antarctic. Higher temperatures have shrunk the Arctic ice area 10% and its thickness 42% in 30 years. The permafrost is shrinking, endangering infrastructure. These changes are threatening the culture and economy of the indigenous Artic population. Ice shelves in the Antarctic are collapsing. The melting of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet could raise ocean levels worldwide approximately 15 feet. Increased tourism in the Antarctic is having an environmental impact. Researchers are debating whether greenhouse gases or natural climate cycles are the biggest cause of the melting.    Collapse of coastal Antarctic ice shelves accelerated eight-fold the seaward flow of inland glaciers, raising sea levels: Larsen A (1995), Wilkins (1998), Larsen B (2002), Larsen C (this century). Currents undermine the Ross and Ronne ice shelves, enabling ice flows from deep within the West Antarctic ice sheet. Arctic permafrost thawed; glaciers and sea ice retreated. In 30 years the Arctic ice cap's area shrank by 10%, its thickness by 42%, opening shorter maritime routes when Arctic sea ice disappears in future summers. Siberian lakes disappeared. Indigenous cultures and glacier tourism suffered. Bird migrations shifted. Northern Hemisphere weather will worsen.    In Antarctica and the Artic, ice melts are causing complex questions about the impact of global warming. In Antarctica huge glaciers are thinning and ice shelves are either disintegrating or retreating. These findings are possible indications of global warming. Information gathered about Antarctica coincides with a recent report on accelerating climate changes in the Arctic. A Chinese scientist predicted that the Artic icecap would melt by 2080. The Arctic's indigenous people (about 4 million) are fighting global warming because it will be a threat to their societies, economies and culture.    The thinning of glaciers and ice shelves, as well as the softening of the permafrost, has accelerated greatly in recent years. While it is not certain that the man-made greenhouse effect is entirely to blame, it is clear that man must take steps now to address the problem. Global warming affects everything: oil-platforms, the society of peoples who are indiginous to the polar regions, polar animals, migratory birds, lakes (which are drying up as the permafrost melts), and even tourism. As melting cold fresh water enters the salty sea, it will affect ocean currents and therefore world climate. </text> <scu uid="17" label="Ice continues to melt in the Arctic">  <contributor
